reviewText:
Early Access Review

Multiplayer-only games are finding themselves in a tricky situation these days now that gamers are expecting a bit more from them. Once upon a time, it was enough to offer an experience specially tailored for a group of friends, but now that multiplayer has become commonplace to the point of being tacked on to most games unnecessarily, multiplayer-only titles are needing to step up their game more than ever. Although Secret Ponchos has blazed onto the scene with hardly any introduction, it does present an interesting, if imperfect, alternative to standard online FPS deathmatches.

Where Secret Ponchos shines is in its creativity, which especially shows in the character designs. Each outlaw has their own specialty and weapons, leaving it up to you to learn their mechanics and choose which style works best for you. While Kid Red is an easy opener, with his quick-firing pistols and room-clearing sticks of dynamite, veterans of twin-stick shooters may be more welcoming to a character like the Phantom Poncho, whose sawed-off shotgun and whip create a devastating combination in both close-quarters and distant combat.

More difficult outlaws come in the form of the Matador, whose ranged weapons are slow to fire and reload, but whose melee capabilities can be devastating if she gets close enough to an enemy. Similarly, the Killer uses a revolver with a low firing rate and an extremely lethargic (yet extremely deadly) dagger that requires much more precision than other outlaws. Finally, the Deserter is a tank through and through, bowling over opponents and blowing them away with single shots.

You’re allowed to create many different outlaws, all of which upgrade separately, and the upgrade system that expands their abilities is actually pretty creative. Players are rewarded a bounty after each match, and after a certain price is reached for your head, you’ll earn a few upgrade points to sink into one of a few categories. Of course, if you perform poorly, your bounty will lessen, leaving you at a disadvantage.

The combat is similar to your typical twin-stick shooter, albeit with a few twists. Characters can disappear for a few seconds if they take cover behind some scenery, and each is saddled with a small amount of stamina used to roll away from danger that is slow to refill but absolutely necessary for a clean getaway or a successful surprise attack. Outlaws are also outfitted with two distinct weapons, both of which have multiple uses that really allow for tons of improvisation and addictive battles.

The art style employed by Secret Ponchos is absolutely bursting with personality and color, making each outlaw a unique creation despite the fact that they never speak. The maps that are available, while small, are beautifully detailed, capturing the essence of old westerns perfectly, from decrepit saloons to rundown graveyards. Even if you don’t enjoy anything the gameplay has to offer, you can still appreciate the loving homages to westerns found throughout the game.

Of course, since Secret Ponchos is still a work in progress, it comes with its fair share of issues, especially regarding the balance of the characters. Simply put, some outlaws are overpowered, especially Kid Red. He can fire the most shots in a row, most of which have the chance to stun the target, leaving enemies a pulpy mess in just seconds. Compared to the slower, more powerful characters, Kid Red completely obliterates the competition.

There’s also a noticeable lack of content, with only a handful of battle modes available as of now. You’ve got your traditional free-for-all, team deathmatch and domination modes, but with only four maps to choose from, things get stale pretty quick. The ability to play locally with split-screen is a great addition, but it does little to add to the replay value.

As enjoyably intense as Secret Poncho can be, with outlaws diving left and right, firing six-shooters and sticks of dynamite at each other in the middle of a dusty graveyard, it’s still a work in progress that suffers from its unfinished nature. Secret Ponchos is an absolute blast that should definitely make its way into your library when its completed. The upgrades that are being promised could elevate it to a whole new level. Until then, however, it’s a fun title that feels incomplete and short on content.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Secret Ponchos is a top-down shooter that looks great, plays great, and has a nice multiplayer. The game has 4 characters in total in the current version of the game with only a few maps to play in, a practice mode, and 2 multiplayer modes. and I'm pretty sure they will add more as time goes on, but this early version (first public version) of the game and it feels great and my purchase is in good hands. From what i can see there will be single-player, split screen gameplay, and maybe coop. But at the moment, if you won't be satisfied with only multiplayer, i'd advise to wait a month or two, but if you don't mind it then go right ahead and get it, it doesn't seem that buggy and fun to play honestly. Plus the art style and the music are really awesome in this game that gives you a feeling of the old west in a cartoon-ish way. Also, these guys are 'good guys devs' , they have PS4 Dual Shock 4 Support for the game on PC. Massive plus.

http://youtu.be/dhri5MxDs6I

Will update when the coop mode / split-screen mode is out, and when the KB/M controls are out.

UPDATE: From what the developers are saying, the 'Coop' is team vs. team multiplayer, there is no coop where you and your friend play against AI in a horde mode or single-player. That's really bad and false advertising if that is actually the case.

The developers see 'coop' as a competitive team vs. team multiplayer as the main definition of the term 'coop' , and such, they do not have the coop that we know as player vs. AI, but they also said that they are not rulling that out, at the moment they are focusing on the multiplayer side of things until launch and may add a singleplayer to the game with a probability of adding team vs. AI.

Devs took the advice and feedback, and will hopefully remove the coop tag from the store page, and will update when it's actually removed (It's removed :) ). So when they do actually add coop, first of all that would be great, secondly then they would add the coop tag in the game's store page. Hurray for polite and constructive criticism.

More info here:  KSalue[www.ksalue.com]

reviewText:
Secret Ponchos is an extremely fun and engageing game with its own unique style of gameplay and charm.
While it may seem like a MOBA, secret ponchos is more akin to a fighting game, requiring the player to rely more on their skill, reaction time and ability to aim than something like a gear setup and just pure numbers.

The game has improved by a lot since its initial early access release with much better matchmaking, the ability for priavte matches, more characters, more maps, more music and single player options for those who cant always find someone to play with or just want to have a simple easy matchup.

The devs are very responsive to community feedback and provide frequent updates to make sure the game is both as balanced and bug-free as possible.

This game is one of a kind and is definetly worth playing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Spaghetti Western themed dramatic action-based multiplayer isometric quick-twitch shooter at it's finest.

If you had an inner-self that wanted to enter a saloon all Clint Eastwood style and just show everyone who is the man then this game might interest you.

This game is still in Early Access  but the community behind it is a bunch of helpful trigger-happy players that just need more people to play with. The game honestly needs more exposure to flourish!

When I think of this game I think of a famous MOBA like Riot's League of Legends, it started out with a group of developers that were just hungry to work on their game, and now it is the most-played PC game worldwide! Why can't Secret Ponchos be one of those titles?
In the words of Switchblade Monkeys (the developers): Fighting mechanics that use quick twitch reflexes
recommended: and precision. Picture a split second dive roll behind cover
hoursPlayed: then rushing a pair of enemies guns blazing as you stun one and gun down the other. Secret Ponchos was not built as a MOBA
voteText:
but as a fighting game that supports fast paced group combat. "


I rate this original upcoming masterpiece a 10/10 and it doesn't burn a whole on your wallet either!            Questions        Answers                Will there be more characters (Outlaws) anytime soon?        Yes.                Are there achievements to collect?        Yes
helpfulPercent: and more on it's way.                Can I whip another player?        Why
votesHelpful: yes of course!\nFrequently updated?        Yes                Do the developers care about the community?        Hell yeah they do."

reviewText:
1st hour on this game: Hm, seems pretty cool.

2nd hour on this game: Found a character I really like to play.

3rd hour on this game: Discovered very high level mechanics. It seems there's quite a bit of depth to it that you normally can't notice first coming in.

4th hour in: I start destroying everyone I play against.

5th hour in: I go against a top level player and get my ♥♥♥ handed to me.

6th hour in: I'm in practice mode trying to learn new combos. I want to be like the best.

7th hour in: I should go to class.

............

15th hour in: Decided I wont be playing anything else for the rest of the year.

10/10 - Get this game.

reviewText:
Absolutely recommend this game. This game's visual style is magnificent but i have to say the music is just top notch. For an indie title like this the soundtracks have an incredible vibe to them and they surely live up to the western theme. Cannot repeat it enough, the music is pure high quality candy for the ears and brain. I would even go so far and say that the soundtracks used in this game are better than most triple A titles nowadays.
The core gameplay mechanic is just fantastic, its fast paced pvp action where u challenge yourself all the time and try to perfect your moves with a character. You definitely will need good reflexes or otherwise you might get rekt really hard. Other than that, i dont see any noteworthy negative aspects except that its playerbase needs to grow. A few bugs here and there but thats ok, they get fixed fast, since the devs seem to work with their heart on this game and thats what makes it even better. You get the best stuff possible from the devs. Its rare to see this type of relationship between a game and its developers, so definitely worth supporting these guys. Keep up the good work and see you ingame!

tl;dr: id r8 this 8/8 m8

reviewText:
I primarily want to write this review because a lot of older negative reviews are just outdated.
Over the last months the developers  improved the game a lot for example with over 500 fixes (including many matchmaking fixes) and keyboard and mouse support :).
In my opinion the outlaws are balanced now and every outlaw feels really different to play with.
Secret Ponchos is also way beginner friendlier now because there is a new AI practice mode where you can basically play with bots ( of course theyre still a little dumb but really helpful to learn combos and stuff :D). Also the importance of perk points (points you get while levelling up to improve your outlaws stats) has been reduced massively so even a player with the lowest rank has a chance against players with the highest rank. Additionally a tutorial has been added and an in game lobby chat where new players can e.g. ask more experienced players for tips.
Another really good thing about this game is that it is really easy to communicate with the devs. They stream Secret Ponchos weekly and talk with the community about changes and future plans on the live stream.
The gameplay is really competitive. The art style and the music are just awesome. So just give the game a shot (whether it will be with Deserters bayonet or The Killers revolver ;) ).
See you out there in Lonetree :D

Update: All the new content that has been added in the Most Wanted Edition makes this game even better and I think everyone should be able to find an outlaw that fits his playstyle because there are 10 unique outlaws now.

reviewText:
I have spent more than 1,000 hours playing this game.

The art and music are all excellent. There are 5 characters who are pretty well balanced for early access. The gameplay itself is simple to learn and has a lot of depth. I can easily spend hours playing this game without getting bored. Whether you win or lose entirely depends upon how you play (or if there's a glitch or bug; this is Early Access after all).

This game has a multiplayer aspect that rivals putting quarters in Street Fighter 2. This is a game where you and your friends will murder each other repeatedly and they will have a good time doing it. Unfortunately, there is no single player, and very few people right now are willing to spend the time to set up a game.

If you enjoy competitive games, this is an absolutely amazing game that you must own. If you have the patience to wait in the chat or set up a game with other people, I would recommend this game to you. If you don't have friends, you might want to reconsider buying this. If you don't have any patience, you should pick a different game entirely because this one will mercilessly crush you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Note: This isn't a proper review, as it's very early in development, I can't properly give it a fair review, instead this is my first impressions, thank you.

Style... this game has got some to spare, but that's not what's important of course, the gameplay is. It seems like a typical twin stick shooter and in many ways, it is, it's meaty though, very meaty, the guns feel good, sound good, feels tight. You'll be dodging, shootan and using your special weapon to try and get kills. Reloading usually takes time, so you must be aware of how many shots you've got left otherwise you could be left stuck in a crowd with no bullets. Taking cover allows you to reload faster, but not many people take cover surprisingly.

When it comes down to it, it's a highly skilled twin-stick multiplayer deathmatch, there's lots of tactics involved and you can turn any bad situation around. It just... feels good to play, it has a lot of potential as an early access game.

reviewText:
First off, I would like to start by saying I NEVER write reviews on my own will but this game has just gave me the warmest feeling in my heart for a multitude of reasons.

This game is a top-down arena type shooter that has aiming, cover, and dodging with a Old Western theme to it and I have to say this game has wowed me. I do NOT like top-downs but somehow this game has bypassed my loathing for the camera angle and become one of the most fun and smoothest games I have played. There is many Outlaws to choose from that you can make your own with a name, a skin, and even their stats are upgradable to fit the playstyle you mainly identify with, as well as you can make as many characters as you want to switch back and forth from.

This game currently has 2 main modes, Competitive and Arcade, Competitive you can either play 3v3 for a fun fast-paced teamfight or a more personal 1v1 brawl, and somehow this game manages to make you grin and have fun even when you are losing terribly.

Now, the game isn't all rainbows in it's current state as it does take a little bit to find matches for some people, and also the party system can be iffy at times but this is NO issue as if you go to the community steam chat (which is linked inside of the game for fast access), the devs are sitting in the chatroom listening to every issue you may have, giving suggestions on how to fix your issues, answering your questions, and even fixing problems WHILE they have a nice chat with everyone! I have not seen a SINGLE game be this involved with the community but it definitely gives them huge bonus points with me!

The game is amazing and frankly quite cheap, I say take a try at it as this is generally a loved game, and if you're scared about the matchmaking issues, have no worry as they will be fixed very soon! 11/10 game for sure from me!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL; DR: Buy it. Despite a small (but growing fast) community its tons of multiplayer strategic fun.

Secret Ponchos puts you in the steel-toed boots of a wild west gunslinger, popping pistol shots into your lilly-livered opponents from across the saloon.

The game has a MOBA-like presentation, but let me stress IT IS NOT A MOBA, it is mechanically similar to a fighting game with its focus on positioning, mindgames, and smart comboing.

At the time of this writing the game has 6 playable characters, each with wholly unique playstyles. The developer plans to have 10 playable characters upon the games full release.

Each character is the embodiment of a certain Western Myth archetype, with a unique primary and secondary weapon that dictates how they respond to enemies. My current favorite is the Killer, a grizzled old man with a sharpshooting revolver and a throwing knife, perfect for zoning opponents and keeping them at bay. Secret Ponchos mines great amounts of depth from the characters' two weapons, with several different attacks per weapon.

The art style is beautiful and gloomy, and it sets the perfect mood for a good ol' gunslinging shootout.

Each of your characters earns experience as you play, which you can use to tweak your Outlaw's stats a bit and tailor them to your strengths or cover your weaknesses.

The game is designed entirely around multiplayer, it is not currently a good single player experience, which is true of any fighting game. There is a rookie" mode so the greenhorns can get their wits about them before playing with the big boys

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Saw this game for the very first time at the Indie showcase at EVO.  Wasn't sure what to make of it.

I got the chance to speak w/ the devs of Secret Ponchos and they explained it to me.

Everyone seems to be trying to get into the MOBA scene these days.  Hell, even Blizzard is.  When it comes to the fighting game scene, new titles come and go; but, its the classic titles/franchises that withstand the test of time.

Secret Ponchos realizes that there are elements from these genres that work well together, creating a blend of gameplay that puts it's foot in a wide area of appeal when it comes to gamers, casual, fun-seeking, hardcore, or just plain competitive.

But, what is it exactly?

Well, its hard to call it one thing.  I'd like to just say its fun; but that doesn't say much now does it? xD

- It is a spaghetti-western themed action-based twitch shooter.

- Its a multiplayer game, for sure.

- It utilizes an isometric view, used in action games and mobas like Diablo, Torchlight, League of Legends, and DOTA 2.

- It features a roster of widely different, but balanced characters, known as Outlaws.

- It features several game modes that allow the player to choose whether they'd prefer to have a classic 1v1 duel or a team based battle or maybe you just want all-out chaos with an 8 player free for all.
- Team battles can be 2v2 or 3v3
- Team battles can be played as deathmatch, with whoever is the last man standing wins for his/her team.
OR, team battles can play in Domination to see which team can outkill their opponents.

- Outlaws are able to use a dodge roll to evade enemy attacks and put distance between them to gain better positioning or a hasty retreat.
- Outlaws can also take cover behind objects to hide themselves or shield themselves from attacks.
- Each character/Outlaw has a different way of fighting that feels unique to them and they all employ 2 weapons, each with primary and secondary attacks, that can be switched back and forth with ease.
- Having 2 different weapons, with each having 2 different ways of attacking adds an intriguing amount of depth and strategy to the combat; especially during team battles.

My Outlaw employed a Gatling Gun as his primary and could utilize a ground slam that let out an aoe stun effect that enveloped a small radius around me.  For my seconday weapon, he possessed a Molotov Cocktail which he could throw and have it explode in an area, giving off an AOE burn effect to anyone unfortunate enough to be caught in it.  It also is able to be used as a close range deterrant by igniting the ground around you, putting flames between you and anyone wanting to get close.

Having these differing ways to attack and defend gives the feeling that its more than just see person
hoursPlayed: capitalizing on your opponents mistakes and knowing when to strike.  The fundamentals of MOBAs are good strategies to use in this game.\n\n- Don't overextend yourself.   Be aggressive
voteText: but not reckless.  Stay with your team.  If you die
helpfulPercent: your team is at a disadvantage. etc. etc. etc.\n\nThe community is small
votesHelpful: but is fun
commentsCount: and approachable.  The devs also enjoy playing the game they made and are easily accessible.  They have a great game here and it can only grow from here.\n\nIt is worth every penny and I look forward to playing it for the rest of early access and beyond release."

reviewText:
Secret Ponchos tries and succeeds to bring something that feels fresh to the table: great gameplay with a few different game modes and maps, strong and unique spaghetti western theme, well balanced and designed characters and a caring community.
The devs are really active and friendly (you can easily find them on the community chat and boards), and the game is regularly patched.

Right now, I think the major issue is the lack of players at certain hours (obviously depending from your region) that can make quite hard finding matches at times. Also, the menus/UI are quite counterintuitive.

Long story short, this is a great game that only needs a bigger playerbase. If it strikes your fancy you won't regret buying it, expecially if you can bring your own posse to the fray.

reviewText:
This is going to be a simple pros and cons list:

Pros:
- Game's aesthetic design is lovely and the wild west theme is applied pretty decently.
- Characters are fitting and unique enough but they haven't created personalities and taunts for them which could make the player feel more attached to characters.
- The thing I hated the most about MOBAs, limiting the game for only one map is not apparent here and most of the maps feel authentic enough.
- All characters have three unique powers which are all fitting to the characters but some of them are useless imo, like The Deserter's impale attack as it takes too long to charge and easy to miss.
- Game feels unique at every aspect.

Cons:
- The game's playerbase is really small. I guess the Steam free weekend is to combat that problem, but at the first day of the free weekend, I still have troubles finding a game.
- Balance is non existant. But this might not be the game's fault but the low playercount's, as the Steamspy statistics show.
- This is only my own opinion but if the game had higher damage and scattered healing stations (it could be wells or travelling doctors to fit the aesthetic)
- There are some weird angles that you can't see where you are or where you're aiming at.
- A simple color change to aiming line, making it bright red instead of faded black would drastically improve playability.
- More objective based modes instead of deathmatch or domination would improve the tactical side of things.
- Steam workshop for characters and maps could do wonders to increase the community forming and involvement alongside with cosmetic drops and marketplace instead of buying skins directly from the developer.
- There is no form for team chat.

This game is not good enough right now, but there are some simple changes that could make it my go to multiplayer game, I hope the developers continue developing and not be downhearted by low player count.

I am recommending you all this game as it is now free and if you want to continue playing, it's cheap enough. I wish they also put 4-pack to the sale so it would see a greater increase in population.

Edit after couple more hours: The game certainly has enough depth and gets better when you start playing with the guys that use their outlaws creatively. Three The Kid dynamite ♥♥♥♥ fest? YOU GOT IT! Deserter tank, phantom kill? For sure mate! It's 6 A.M here now and I don't want to sleep to continue playing the game, I haven't felt this about a game since Skyrim.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'll start off with my grievance of this game:

There aren't enough players in it at the moment. Every night I have to find players I know that play the game and gather them at 8pm pst to see if we can round up 4 to play. I just wish there was enough to just hop on and join at any time of day, but unfortunately these are the problems of an alpha or beta or whatever.


BUT, that is the only major downside to it. There are so many positives to this game, I would still give it 5/5 if I could. The characters, the artwork, the sound, the animations, the controls....all have such depth and you can feel a backstory to them that the developers have bled into the game.

As for my grievance, the developers hold a twitch stream where you can play them and also partake in dialog with them about questions you have or suggestions you bring to the table. From these meetings, I have gained an in depth understanding of their direction of where they want to take the game, the reasoning behind their decisions, and the motivation behind their work. Some games on steam that are still in develop like Secret Ponchos just take your money and pooping a game on your hard drive, but unlike those games, Secret Ponchos has such a solid foundation and it's easy to see the developers have the passion to make this one of the best games of 2015.

Feel free to add me if you wish to get the game and want to join up with the regular players of the game during devlopment.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

♥ NOT Pay To WinExtremely important and part of the first set of questions I asked their team. They confirmed new characters and skins will be added in the future as DLC, but no player will have an advantage by spending more money in the game. There's even a chance we'll have every character unlocked on practice mode, so we can try before we buy and who doesn't love that?

♥ Controller + Mouse and Keyboard SupportJust pick what you prefer and rebind if needed!

♥ Constant UpdatesCurrently, they'll release major content updates every week until full release, can't wait!

♥ SupportFor an indie studio, they are freaking amazing. You can see 3 employees constantly active in the group chat answering questions and setting up matches to play with everyone.

♥ CommunityRight now it's honestly very small, but solid. We meet up every night to play, discuss and welcome new players. I've personally invited at least 10 players to the group in just a few days after the June 02 update to spread the word even more.

☹ BalanceThe game still needs some balancing tweaks so any character can win against the rest with enough practice. After trying the game for the first time 10 months ago, this has been greatly improved. Developers are open to feedback and constantly tweaking the characters, so I think having a balanced game on release is possible.

☹ AnimationsStill needs improvement. Being a competitive multiplayer game, this needs to be especially polished. I can feel the animations are sloppy sometimes and the gameplay doesn't have the flow it should have. The game isn't finished yet, so I can understand this and hope it's one of their priorities.

TL;DR Highly recommened, see you at the gun fight! (conclusion in the comments area)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Having played over hundreds of hours, I can say Secret Ponchos is a blast to play.  If you are into competitive online multiplayer and love versus type games, give this a try!

In total, there are now 6 unique characters to pick from.  The latest update(June 2nd) just released a new character with more to come. The game is continuing to evolve and update with new modes, characters, maps, and eventually cosmetic skins.

The new main versus mode is rank 1 vs 1 or 3 vs 3. In solo mode, it is a deathmatch with no repawns and best out 3 rounds.  For Team vs mode, it can be a team deathmatch or domination mode.  Domination mode allow respawns and the object is to be the first team to reach 5 kills over the other team or have more kills when the timer runs out.

New players should definitely check out the practice/tutorial mode and the ai modes to learn their characters.   Also try out rookie mode before the rank modes.

Despite being a small indie game developer, Switchblade Monkeys are usually available and very responsive to user questions, concerns, and feedback.

There is a promotion right now for the game and it does not break the bank so get it now and play!

reviewText:
A great game!I was very happy to find something refreshing and different. If you're curious what it plays like, imagine you took some of the most fun, yet simple, aspects of shooters, fighting games, and MOBAS and mixed them together.


Shooters:
Cool guns
Ammo/Reloading
Taking Cover
Fighting Games:
Every character has their own moves/techniques (no fireball motions or anything like that though)
Fighting Games/MOBAS:
Footsies
Combos
Mindgames
MOBAS:
3/4 view/top down 3rd person perspective
A large arena-like area to fight in with well thoughtout terrain placement
Semi-fog of war, if you are behind cover opponents can't see you

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is both really fun but also frustrating because you level up and level down too but thats also what makes it fun and addicting. Secret Ponchos is different than most shooters because you have a stamina bar and certain moves or combos you can do with both weapons. reviewText:
Early Access Review

Even in early Access Secret Ponchos is an incredibly satisfying and addictive game. It looks like a traditional MOBA at first glance, but relies heavily on reflex and twitch actions. The game has a lot of character; music, design, and art direction are all executed well, adding a certain level of polish one does not expect. Gameplay rewards a player who can read situations well and coordinate actions with teammates. The classes are all fairly balanced as well, maybe not the case in a 1v1 scenario, but most definitely in a 2v2 scenario.

Currently the game modes are narrow, and finding a game can sometimes take awhile due to the low population. These issues have not cut into my own enjoyment of the game. The game does have a number of glitches that can become annoying and affect one's performance. I will note that after one day of owning the game patches have corrected several glitches I had been experiencing. The game is not optimized to run on the PC, also. These are all problems that are currently being adressed by the creators of the game.

Buying an early access game is always somewhat terrifying when perusing through Steam's catalog. However, Switchblade Monkeys have delivered a quality product.

reviewText:
I've enjoyed this game a great deal over the free week. I've spent a lot of time trying all the different classes and matchups at different skill levels, as well as played with friends. Ultimately I won't be buying the game afterwards, but I've had a great 25-ish hours in the week.

The good:
-The game's theme is fantastic, a nice western shooter really tightly put together. Instead of getting a ranking you get a bounty and a wanted poster. All the characters are visually very distinctive, even in their different skins. The maps are typical western tropes - train tracks, a ruined village, a gold mine - all the game would need is a tumbleweed going by to be fully there, but that would be visually quite distracting.

-The music is especially good at setting the scene. It seems to be dynamic, picking up when the action starts up. It's proper showdown music, and totally badass in places. The soundwork makes good pistol ricochet noises, but some concessions are made for gameplay elements - when an arrow crits, it makes a satisfying loud crit sound but not really an arrow sound. One neat gameplay element is there is a character that can blind you with dust - but you still hear their sounds as they move around you. It's just one of the many small things this game lets you use to your advantage.

-The gameplay is pretty well balanced. There are 9 asynchronous classes, and I've played them all to at least 'outlaw' level, where the game opens up and you can play people of higher skill. My experience is that the mastery of the class and the game has always been the deciding factor.

-The game is a blast with friends! There's a lot of room for teamwork or silly strats, or just rp the wild west. The game makes some great moments like a shootout in an abandoned church, or a misfired dynamite blowing your teammates up. The matches are short enough that you can get a bunch of these moments with different people in one sitting, often running into the same people over many matches.

-The community is encouraging. I've come across a few moba players spewing rage at their teammates and lag and the like, or a few people with really racist or offensive names, but for the most part people have been friendly and communicative. You know what everyone likes? Dumb jokes about the wild west and westerns. It seems universal.

-The devs have been really communicative and patient throughout the free week, posting a bunch of fixes and faqs and answering questions in the community chat all week. That's really promising, like if the game gets a following it seems like development will continue.


The bad:
-The game, while balanced, only really feels balanced at the top end - at lower levels you'll currently find the killer and deserter classes really strong compared to the others. Even at the top end it feels a bit sketchy - I went 2-0 against one of the top 5 players with the killer (with only 10 games under my killer's belt), which I probably shouldn't be able to do playing from a free week. Likewise I got 2-0'd by a deserter after doing twice the damage he did, but I feel that had I played him more I would have found his weakness.

-While I have had a blast over the free weekend, I do worry about the size of the playerbase after it's over. Even over the free weekend I ran into the same people many times (this is likely to do with me queuing in the UK, smaller than america). Is it worth the risk of buying a game that could possibly be empty?

-The game is pretty polished, but there are a few things that bugged me. First and foremost the lack of team chat. In a game where you play as a team, why can't we tactic as a team? So it turned out looking into this that the game did in fact have a team chat - if you /t into speak you can chat with your team. However, this is the only way of doing it and it's completely undocumented - I found out from a buried forum post. There are some menu difficulties too - why do I have to escape out of a chat window? Why does random mode only random 2 modes when there are 3? Why must I leave a party to change class?

-The other thing is the latency and network issues. It's not TOO bad but it makes some things difficult - particularly guns that put you into the hurt animation or whatever, if you're playing someone across the pond you can get violently stunlocked. Projectiles you've clearly dodged end up hitting you, that sort of thing. The game feels like it would be fantastic on a lan where you can all talk with each other and there's no ping issues, but over the wild wild web it suffers a bit.

-There is no punishment for people being abusive or trolling. People can have racist names, teamkill your team (if I didn't mention it anywhere else, this game has friendly fire always on, magicka style), say nasty stuff, with no way of reporting them. Leaving a game costs 300 bounty, which means you can leave early every other game and still keep an even keel on bounty. (I have also lost 300 bounty when the opposing player left the game early in 1v1 sometimes) While the developers are actively working on the game this is fine, but it needs improvement if the playerbase goes critical.

Overall, the game is totally worth your time, I had a blast. It's twitchy, it's strategic, it's funny.

reviewText:
You've probably come down here to see if this game is worth your fist full of dollars*. So let me discuss the good, the bad and the ugly that this game has to offer.

First of all it should be said that the game is a lot of fun, and for that reason alone I can recommend it.  It is challenging, skill based and seems pretty well ballanced. The devs actively engage with the community and are open to suggestions. And contrary to a claim by a certain well known reviewer, the game does have a practice mode where you can try each of the outlaws either in a free for all brawl against 3 AI opponents, or in the same level with said opponents disabled.

Now despite the goodness this game has to offer it is not without its flaws. The settings available at this point in time can be rather lacklustre for some players, and the community is small enough to make matchmaking a bit of a hassle at times, particularly on slow days. The matchmaking issues also mean that it is harder to get teams of around the same skill level, although a recent patch has tried to alleviate that by trying to shuffle (non-premade) teams so that they are more even, rank wise. Still this system isn't always 100% effective, as one of the first matches I played after the patch was implemented shows. Another (rather) experienced player and myself got matched up against a pair of new players.

Overall I recommend you give it a try, though it might take you more than the 2 hours that steam allows for a refund in order to get into the game. If you're worried about the population you can buy the four pack for a few dollars* more, and gift some spare copies to your friends. That way you're at least assured of a few 2v2 matches.

*Or other currencies that don't make for good spagetthi western puns.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A game that's featured at EVO is usually a big deal.  Being a Referee at EVO 2015 decided to take a break and ended up playing this game for hours. This game had people screaming with excitement and suspense. The mechanics are easy to get used to, around 2-3 games. Once you get the mechanics down you can branch from multiple characters to chose from all with their own awesome abilities.

What I enjoy the most is the combos you can land with each character. It's not a game where some characters counter others or some are stronger. It is all about skill and how you use your stamina bars. Some one can land a combo without taking any damage while another can miss that combo and end up losing a chunk of their health. The characters are balanced, all are unique, and all have their mechanics to understand and combos.

This game is by far my top 5 indie/ video game. If you want to play just join the awesome community or seatch for a game. Everyone seems to be friendly here. give it a shot. Im going to buy some extra keys and give away on my streams on Twitch come check it out.

reviewText:
A PvP where the quick survive and the quickest thrive.

Pros:
+ Great Artwork/Style that reminds me of the Gorillaz
+ An underused setting (The Spaghetti West)

Cons:

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Twin stick shooters have been coming back for a while now, and Secret Ponchos is no exception to this revival. Old school gameplay mechanics mean you are relying on skill and reaction time to win. It's

I really enjoy the multiplayer in this game because its really competitive. Each character's unique skillset means a good balance of characters vs. skill on your team could be the difference between winning and losing. If everyone is running melee characters versus the more slower, long range character types it can completely flip the scales of the game. However, there are some people who just find great skill with one or two characters and regardless of what they're up against they've managed to master the art of the twin stick mechanic and own people. There is a great dynamic in place that keeps the game fresh, especially with the varying playstyles you'll find while playing.

There is most likely a character you'll align with even if you're predominantly an FPS/3rd Person shooter player, and while the twin stick aiming is harder to master than traditional FPS games, it's not an impossible thing to master. Take your time, learn the mechanics, and enjoy the game. It's a great competitive community and I'm really excited to see the next wave of players join in on the fun.

In short, I recommend the game for the fun casual mp with friends, and the competitive team-based aspect when playing against randoms online.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is awesome, but I can't ever find people to play with!!!

Ok, I don't have a lot of hours tracked yet but as they accrue I'll update my review. Initial impressions I was a bit disappointed because the game appears deceptively simple, but don't let that fool you. More people need to play this game, it's a ton of fun. Once you're in a multiplayer room you'll start finding that the game is VERY addicting! The game itself is polished and stylized in a way that gives it a distinctive flavor and dexterity. It's a snappy fast reacting game.

The developers are very proactive and will speak with you one on one if you have constructive feedback which is a refreshing take on gaming (I come from experiencing horrible alternatives i.e. Blizzard Entertainment). Some feedback I'd give the developers: After a player has joined a group or party in a public match don't have it disband automatically after a match and rather have people elect to leave. That way you keep people playing without having to reque. Maybe consider chat channels in the title screen to have clan chat or a channel to create games in, talk about strategy, or anything else the community may want to use to connect their experiences in a visible way.

As far as a message to gamers: Really try this game out, don't let the initial simplicity fool you and give the experience a shot. You'll be pleasantly surprised.

reviewText:
Secret Ponchos has been released AT LAST !!
I reviewed the game in august 2014 and i was disapointed by the lack of players.

IT'S TIME TO UPDATE A REVIEW FOR AN EXCELLENT GAME !


Plot: You're an outlaw in the West. Each characters with it's own background and style, they compete for fame as the most dangerous.... and now it's time for you to prove you have what it takes !

Graphics:Cell Shading cartoonish Western Spaghetti is a delight for eyes if you are like me an absolute fan of westerns.
The game has a real atmosphere and characters have a lot of charisma. You don't fall into usual clichés and it's a good point, the game has its own personality and it's a real pleasure to fight in Secret Ponchos's levels. Levels are viewed from above and you follow your character the same way, only aiming moves the camera a bit and can be tricky because of some walls. Also menus are clear and simple. Secret Poncho is a very nice looking game if you like cartoons and cell shading.

Controls:You can play with keyboard, for the first hours it will be okay.
But a gamepad is a must. When in ranked matches where anythings acts in a matter of seconds, playing with sticks and buttons is perfect. Especially because of the fact that you have to swap betweens your weapons/abilities very often.
If you have a gaming mouse with side buttons it might be better but i still prefer the gamepad.
You have been warned !

Music:A bit shy" sometimes
date:
it's of course in the mood of the title. Very nice to ear and doesn't bother you at anytime.
Maybe more different tracks for menus and more in-game actions impact. A music full of tension when showdowns turns into real duels would have been great !


Gameplay:Secret Ponchos is a multiplayer arena based action game. Criminals fights each others in differents maps and modes from deathmatch in teams
recommended: free for all or domination. Matches are fast but intense
hoursPlayed:
around 5 mins per fights.

You can play a small tutorial (one tutorial per character would have been great) and an arcade mod to pratice and find your favourite outlaw.
And talking about outlaws every characters has skills and stats
voteText:
you can open a menu at any time by pressing left arrow to see movements combos and understand how to play them. You can also create as many characters as you want and customize them at your will because every skill point spent can be used on any other stats bars. Experience gain by characters is measured by cash earned after every fights and represent the bounty placed on your outlaw's head.
Every titles represents a certain amount of money and determines what kind of player you will find in ranked matches.
You can still fight in unranked matches but results still affect your progress.

The game is extremely hard and every encounter will be a challenge. You have to take cover
helpfulPercent: dodge
votesHelpful: watch your allies to prevent that your skills wont incapacitate them
votesTotal: reload your weapons or even check your abilities cooldowns. Many factor makes combats very dynamics and requires a lot... A LOT of skill to bring sufficient pleasure.\nFirst times are though especially if you are like me
votesFunny: a complete noob and unable to check character's movements menu before first online matches....\nBut one of the most interresting feature in Secret Poncho is a presence of lines of sights and aiming. You can flank players if you crawl behind covers or when you have to draw your weapon
commentsCount: you will see on the ground your range and the appropriate way your ammo will follow. Your enemy can see it too wich makes fights really quick and tight !\n\nLife Span:10 outlaws. 8 Alternate Skins. Tons of titles/ achievements to grind. Very hard characters to master. Very hard maps to master (around 10 for the moment and all excellent). 3 different modes from deathmatch
column17: i would like to see more modes and maybe objective based ones (with so much content allready in the game
column18:
it's completely possible to add such modes... only players feedback and sells can help in this way !).
Add to that a very good community that is NOW on the game and it was about time !
And you can guess that Secret Poncho has a huge life span and glorious days ahead if you can endure it's difficulty.

Stress/ Fun:Secret Ponchos can be really difficult and even a nightmare if you don't pratice during few hours. As i said before don't hesitate to check movements menus (left arrow son !). Also characters are all special and it will take time (or not) for you to find your favourite. Also some teams layouts are horribly strong and without any organisation or communication you won't stand any chances. Alone you can still have fun but playing with friends is a must... especially if they are in the enemy team !
Remember that's it's a skill based game so be prepared to smash your keyboard especially when an ally can blow
column20:
stun you during fights ^^


TO CONCLUDE:
A BLAST ! Secret Ponchos is a gem
column22: the game has done quite a lot of work and succeeded in its attempt to increase player base. Secret Poncho has no interrest in solo mode
column23:
it's a full multiplayer game and requires a lot of patience and skill to get into.

So now Kid

reviewText:
Early Access Review

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4nkj8eMwciE&feature=youtu.be
Multiplayer is a hard section to get into in gaming now a days, between COD, battlefield, and CS. Its even harder to get be successful in the Moba business, with games LOL and Dota, its even harder when you're not free to play. Well Secret Ponchos not be considered a normal Moba, but it does have an online store where you can buy skins, and takes place from an overhead view. It also has a difficulty curve like a brick wall that is common to mobas, it also has the twitchy gameplay. Unlike a moba every hit you make is a press of a button, there is no animation that plays, no auto attacks, no creeps, no item shop. So when it comes to genre the game falls in a weird spot. Its also a western which most mobas either are fantasy or Sci-fi. But the western setting backs up the twitch gameplay with the draw of a gun and only a few shots fired before looking for cover.
The art style is comic booky and the characters are  weirdly rigid and it implies a sense of humor, but the game is so intense that it undermines its artistic integrity and…..

This game contradicts itself a lot.

Secret ponchos is a stylish and original spaghetti western multiplayer combat game. That ones straight from the steam page. Its also says its a quick-twitch fighter, all of these things are true.
The gameplay of the game is fast as a quick draw, wow great joke right? Its a dual stick shooter that uses every button on the controller except for right and left on the d pad. Each button has a different function except for a and left bumper both share the cover button. Each Character in the game has 2 weapons and each weapon has 2 fire modes and there are 5 characters which adds to a total of 20 attacks across 5 characters and leads to all sorts of tactics.

and I really feel like i'm getting ahead of myself. Ok lets start at the beginning
when you start you are asked to make a character and name them. There are 5 characters with different stats that after you select them you can upgrade through a point system like in tony hawk. The Only game mode as of now is a 2v2 domination mode in which the opposing teams fight to kill each other. If your team gets a kill the counter adds a point  if the enemy team gets after that kill you lose that point and the first team to get 5 points wins. After each round you are given a bounty, if you win your bounty will go up, if you lose your bounty will decrease. The bounty acts a a leveling system if you get 1000 bounty you will level up and become a higher level criminal, and also get more points to upgrade your stats, but since you can lose bounty if you go under that 1000 you will go down and lose the stat boosts that go with it.

Now to talk about the combat. The combat in this game is surprisingly deep, allowing you to employ many tactics against your foes. The game also does have a difficulty curve like a brick wall as i mentioned earlier and takes a good 4 to 5 hours of gameplay to adjust to the game. The games many weapons each have different effects, some have blast damage, some stun your opponent, some allow you to dodge and its how deploy these to your advantage is what makes the combat deep. Another layer to combat is Team Comp since it is 2 v 2 you have another player with you. Unfortunately you can't switch characters on the fly so you may end up with someone that compliments your play style or some that hinder it. But the game allows duplicates to play in the same match so you may end up with 4 grim reapers all duking it out. Friendly fire is also on so you have to be careful around your teammate. You also have a dodge mechanic that lets you dodge roll 3 times but then has to regen. You also have a cover mechanic that you have to throw in there as well. So with all this stacked on top of each other what combat usually looks like is a slow approach to the enemy team taking cover along the way. Then a short but violent skirmish and if you're still alive dashing away to find cover again. But in that moment of skirmish every second counts depending on who is using which of their 4 attacks, weather or not you miss, how many dodges  they have all of it determines the outcome of the battle.  You may win and walk away without a scratch or your team mate might die and you get left to have to run from 2 armd killers.

Now i know i've talked really good about the game so far so im gonna rattle off the things that irk me about the game.

Even though there is a ranking system it doesn't matter even if you are lowest level you can still get have to go against someone with the max bounty on their head.
The hit boxes sometimes really screw up
If you accidentally disconnect from a match you can't reconnect.
Alot of general glitches
The game has no tutorial (witch would really help the difficulty curve problem.)
The fact that it wants you to purchase skins in a paid moba, an early access one at that.
Playing with friends is a pain. Every time you start the game you have to invite them to the lobby witch is normal. But after the match is over it kicks them and you have to re invite your friends to the lobby to play another match. At one point we all had to restart our clients to even to connect to each other.
Now I know its early access but this really need to be addressed since this is a multiplayer game and playing with friends is a big draw to the game. Unfortunately the hassle to get with friends almost isnt worth it.

Despite all that the game is rewarding and addictive enough to encourage you to climb that brick wall of difficulty curve, and the fights are so fast and fun that the game will keep you playing all the way to High Noon.

Thumbs up:

reviewText:
Nothing in this game works.

Multiplayer:
I use the clumsy friend invite GUI (lists friend, requires you to scroll, instead of just using the Steam overlay) to invite my friend. My friend gets nothing. Instead, it send an invite to an entirely different person on my friends list, who after a few tries messages me that the spam is getting a little bit annoying.
Having my friend invite me works to put us into the same lobby, but then the lobby breaks apart while searching for matches. This last bit is acknowledged by the developers in an in-game warning, with them claiming to be working on a fix.

Singleplayer (this game is not meant for SP):
The game pits me in a 1v1 (best of 3 rounds) against the Secret Poncho. After I effortlessly dispatch my foe in the first round, ... nothing happens. The round does not end. Reluctantly I wait for the time to run out, whereupon I am greeted by a never-ending black screen and loud game music. Had to alt-F4 to escape the bugs.


P.S.:
The tutorial:
Press A to continue to the next tutorial segment or B to restart this tutorial segment."
Followed by
"Press A to restart the tutorial or B to continue to the main menu."
Jolly UX

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game grabbed me with it's style.  It's got the bone spit and grit of Sergio Leone meets Tarantino.  The arts and music are incredible, but I was pleased to find the gameplay matches up too.  It's an isometric arena type of pvp experience, but the style of gameplay is much newer and fresher.  It really captures that feeling of western shootouts, run and gun, take cover, reload, wait and ambush, go in guns blazing, did they hole up in the mission?  We'll smoke 'em out with dynamite, etc, etc etc.  Unlike most video games I've played in the western genre, which feel more or less like any shooter with a western skin, this one actually plays like I'd imagine a western shootout.  Limited ammo, cover for reloading, every shot counts, etc.

It's alot of fun.  The makings of a great game are already in place, I hope enough people find this gem, because it'd love to see how it grows.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What can i say about Secret Ponchos?

Well, I picked it up at Evo last weekend for the first time and basically fell in love with it- as a competative gamer it really appeals to my in terms of the sheer number of decisions you make though the well-paced matches, starting with character team comps and moving into adjusting strats between matches. The game has easy to learn and simple controls that mix with phenominal character balance to really make the game lean on each players skill and teamwork abilities rather then simply picking what is considered best. After hanging out with the Dev team for the better part of the weekend, its very clear to me this sort of gameplay matters to them, and they're very activly looking to enchance the game and make it its best.

At the time of this review, there are a few minor things to work out, but hardly anything that ruins the fun or balance of the game- mostly just clarification things that are easily fixable with a few visual aids and are learnable on the player side by watching and learning as you go.

Secret Ponchos is clearly a labour of love that will only get better as the Steam community grows and the devs recieve more and more feedback on how to make the game better. A fun, fast paced, no BS game with unlimited replay value. A must have, certainly.

reviewText:
Secret Ponchos is a charming third-person action game where variably grotesque bandits fight to the death in gladiator style combat.

There are many fun characters for you to choose from. They each wield a unique set of weapons, but which ultimately boil down to a frontal ranged attack or an unintuitive melee attack.

Aside from my personal issues with framerate and overall pacing, I've had a lot of fun playing this game and am now getting romped in Ranked. I would very much like to play this with a friend or two and develop strategies to execute in game.

Overall, the better the community for this game, the better it will become.

Final note: They need to fix typing speed. I type quickly and the chat box does not receive input well.

reviewText: A very smooth and beautiful game set in the wild west, featuring stereotypical gunmen battling for outlaw and vigilante supremacy. Secret Ponchos is a top-down team shooter based around spacing and aiming, with emphasis on the different characters' weapons rather than skills. Fights are quick and snappy, with players having to take aim at the opposing team while simultaneously dodging and weaving through the rain of bullets they're putting down. Combining the strengths of the different Outlaws affects the outcome in many ways, ensuring that there is no real optimal" team.\n\nVisually
date: the game is stunning. The outlaws and environments are perfect in the classic west setting. The outlaws themselves are stylized in a very dark
recommended: cartoonish way that fits the game's theme. Each of them are statistically and visually different from one another so that you can always tell the group apart.\n\nThe soundtrack is phenominal
hoursPlayed: sounding exactly as though it was from a classic spaghetti western film. It never feels intrusive or like just background noise. The guitars and trumpets flaring up press you forward subconciously
voteText: adding drama and intensity to your gunfights as you both linger on the verge of death.\n\nAll in all
helpfulPercent: Secret Ponchos is one of the best team shooters I've played
votesHelpful: and I reccomend it to anyone who digs wild west games or movies."

reviewText:
Quick Review: Recommended if you like playing this style of game online. Buy and play now, as there are quite a few players at the moment. This would also make a good LAN party game.

Secret Ponchos is a nice twin stick shooter that feels great with a controller. You can level up your favorite characters and assign skill points to customize their traits to your playstyle. The developers have been applying feedback and even play each weekend. Each character has different dodge and primary/secondary attacks as well as differing strengths and weaknesses.

In the future this game might be dead, there isn't much in the way of singleplayer, besides bot arcade" battles and practice mode
date: so if you're interested in playing it online with random players buy now. I'll update this review in the future and let you know if it's still recommended with the player pool at the time."

reviewText: Community is a bit harsh, only played the game for a short while on unranked and teammates were unhelpful and ridiculed me.  The game would be a lot more fun with friends. reviewText:
Reviewing Secrect Ponchos
Firstly I never knew about this game until a friend recommeneded to me because I like these sort of games and even though I quite bad at this game I still recommend it because:

Positives of this game:
- There are a varity of characters to choose from which are all kinda balanced(Some characters are good and beat other champions)
- There are 10 maps that have small to large area to fight in.
- In ranked matches you can upgraed your outlaw to gain perks +2% per perk point.
- There aren't that many game modes yet but if you join extra ones will be available because our community will grow. atm there is already ranked 1v1 and 3v3 unranked 2v2 practise and arcade mode.
- Great community most people in chat are really nice if you bring a good attitude with you.
- This game is not pay-to-win you can pay but its only for skins and Some other things nothing that can help you win though so its all skill based.

Negatives of this game:
- There are a few bugs in this game but what can you expect it is a new game and there are treads where you can post it the developers will fix it eventually.
- The community is quite small but its only early time in this game so more people will join soon(hopefully)


I'm not trying to sound bias but there isn't really anything bad about this game its all balanced based off skill not who has the most money. Please join this game, it is great and its loads of fun hanging with friends and a lovely community.

reviewText: I got it in a humble bundle, and it was sincerely the thing I was looking forward to most in the bundle. The concept is great, as well as the art, but there is a great frustration to a third-person team shooter when the average latency between players causes a fair amount of earned hits to miss. Ultimately I found myself just increasingly frustrated with each match, even after investing enough time to become competent with the controls and strategy.\n\nAnyways, it is an attractive game and for $5-10 I would say it could be worth it. I will state I was impressed with the cover mechanics: you can crouch behind most any wall/object on the map, which will hide you from view (okay that sounds pretty basic but for a third-person game its a nice tool). Still, I wont invest any more time to it and for $15 bucks I wouldnt advise others. But see what recommenders say, maybe I just had my expecations set too high.

reviewText:
This game is absolutely fantastic. The core gameplay is excellent, the setting is great, the graphics are solid all-round, and the sound is good.

Secret Ponchos is a top down, highly-competetive arena brawler, featuring a range of unique western-themed characters, each with their own abilities. It's high skill ceiling coupled with tight mechanics make this an excellent PVP game.

However, it's lacking in players. But don't let this put you off! Don't be part of the problem. For every person that says 'I'm not going to get this game, there's too few people playing, it'll take forever to find a game!' that's one less player that's curbing the problem.

This game doesn't just need players, it deserves them!

reviewText:
This game is a hidden gem, i stumbled across it after seeing the free weekend and within my first hour i paid the $8 for the full game. Character selection, balance and artwork. Beautiful game made by a small group of friends.
Pros
-Artwork artwork artwork
-I havent had any trouble connecting to games or friends

-Matches are long enough to be worth it and short enough that you arent stuck with a bad team for too long

Cons

-I love the graphics but my rig can run with with two eyes closed, i wish there was an ultra graphics option.

This game is going to take off and for the 50% off weekend you cant lose! Also This wasnt made by an entire company its just some people making it from home and i am excited to support that!

reviewText:
The team at Switchblade Monkeys put together a wonderful game. The art style draws you in with its unique aesthetic, and the welcomes you into the world of Lone Tree. The gameplay is fast paced, and incredibly fun - some might even say its slightly addicting. Matches are quick and action packed. It gets your adrenaline going from the start. I have no problem recommending this game, to anyone looking for a unique PvP experience. The game mechanics have sufficient depth to lend themselves to a high skill cap hardcore players can enjoy, yet simple and intuitive enough that casual players can pick up easily and have fun as well.

You can tell that the development team is incredibly passionate about this game, and are constantly working on improving the game to make Secret Ponchos a cant miss title. Give it a try, you might fall in love with it just like I did.

See you in the land of Lone Tree,

reviewText:
So Secret Ponchos is a mix of isometric top down shooter and fighting games. Visually it looks like the former, but mechanically it is more akin to a fighting game, albeit one with a perspective flip.

Pros  Cons  Characters and setting are really enjoyable, lots of variation in playstyles and maps.  Occaisional bugs, I get one where the ground doesn't render. No idea if this happens to other players.  Gameplay is solid and enjoyable. Simple enough to pick up fairly quickly, nuanced enough to keep you interested.  Community is pretty miniscule, can be long waits to find a game. Best luck is trying for 1v1 games. Stat builds for individual characters allow you to further tune your playstyle apart from character choice. Increase health, damage, speed, rate of fire, and stamina regeneration. Some newer characters don't seem to be fully fleshed out as of yet, such as the Lawman who has no special ability of his own.
Lots of fun but the lack of community is the biggest failing of the game. Only time will tell if this is remedied. For now it's worthwhile as long as you have a couple of friends equally keen to play, and on sale it's probably worth it just for the few games you'll get out of it.

reviewText:
******Last update most likely


Game unforantely has burnt out with almost no one left playing, people looking for a populated game should most likely consider they will be waiting for ages for matches or need to use group chat to get a match.

This game is still recommended if you have friends you can convince to get it to play with you guys will have a blast.

Its a sad world we live in its very hard for an indie dev to get a competitive shooter off the ground with so much already on the market. I would like to note that the devs of SP are an awesome bunch and poured a lot of hard work into this game and hope they know it doesn't go unnoticed I'll be looking for more releases from this studio for sure.



****** Full release review

After having a good time in the early access portion of Secret ponchos I was really excited for the full release with all the new content and man am I happy to report it was worth the wait!!!!!

The game at its core is a fighting game, essentially its Powerstone for those of you who played that gem on DreamCast back in the day. Combine that with League of legends style skill shooting and you have Secret ponchos!!!

My favorite part of Moba style games has always been the hero vs hero aspect of it not the creep killing. Skill shot fighting is so much fun and this game does really well at utilizing it and turning it into a fun arcade style fighting game.

Core mechanics of the game feel really smooth, I've been using an xbox 360 controller and will most likely move to steam controller for the game but KBM work really well for this as well, maybe even better for certain characters depending on your skill lvl with each periphrial.

Sound is really good in the game, gun shots sound nice the crack of a whip the breaking of a moltov cocktail all of it feels well placed.

Visual look is somewhat comic booky and I really enjoy that estetic.

Price, for the cost of this game I feel like your getting a lot, if you have some friends to play with this little gem could be your go to for a fighting game easily, if you don't have friends interested in this genre I would still recommend it as the community is great, finding matches is quick and the devs play often as well which is even more fun!

I would recommend giving this game a go if it even peaks your intrest slightly you'll most likely enjoy it. Keep in mind it takes a lot of learning and people online are really good! Your going to get your butt kicked until you get good I can promise you that!






******Early Access review

Really fun game so far! Looking forward to putting some hours into it and getting good.


Supports both KBM and Controller I personally like KBM controls for this, small community right now but with great potental for growth just be patient when looking for a match some times it takes several minutes.

Most of the community seems to use the group chat function, I highly recommend this for anyone playing its a great way to connect with everyone and get matches faster.

Devs are very active in communicating with the community.

Very worth picking up right now as you get a copy for free for a friend!

reviewText:
Secret Ponchos

....a game that combines skill based gameplay alongside a western theme, which provides a brand of uniqueness

the game has a variety of western themed characters in the game, from western cowboys, mexican themed outlaws, to native american characters, and yes... a roided out civil war deserter , all of which bring a unique fighting style with all their weapons and skills

the game's art style quite colorful and vibrant, comining the stereotypical western scene plus amazing soundtracks combined, does a spectactucal job of bringing the feel of death and duel to field,

the game definetly has alot of potential and is incredibly fun to play, the feel is similar to that of the likes of BLC  (blood line champions), where skill matters a whole lot, some characters do have some bad match ups, but a skilled player can still out play anyone

im not going to say that every character is good, as some just fall short, when comparing them to other characters, but the developpers are quite active, and balancing of the game is definetly possible

the game is being developped by some of the most active team ive seen, they care so much about their game, and communicate with such politeness with the community to get the game on the right track, that alone deserves respect

however like BLC (blood line Champions), the game suffers from the lack of publicity, and has a small player base which does make matchmaking sometimes to be a pain

the game features 1v1 and 2v2 at the moment, the game did have a 3 v 3...but was removed, however plans to return 3 v 3 is there

overall the game is DEFINETLY worth a shot

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I guess to start off Ill just say that I'm generally not a fan of intense multiplayer only head to head action (and this one is eyeball to eyeball), it's not that there isn't lots of rad games that fall under the category; It's that I find them to be abit too...well...intense!
That being said I quite litterally can't get enough of this marvelous gem of a game!
The developers seem truly dedicated to their community and producing the best game they possably can, a glance at their forums (and this delightful 40% off plus a free copy for a friend deal that is currently running as I write this review) makes that quite clear.
The gameplay is fast and furious and highly rewards skill over spamming buttons, your aim must be true and wasting shots will leave you wishing you hand't, Initially I frowned at the thought of no auto reload but quickly realized how well it lends itself to the whole wild west shootout feel, finding out your gun is empty just as you try and put the finishing shot into your prey creates for fantastic scrambles and shifts in momentum!
There is line of sight and a cover system that allow for sneaky ambushes and low down and dirty shootouts, the ability to destroy much of said cover also lends itself quite nicely to the wild west theme as tombstones crumble around your shoulders while you frantically reload, hoping that they wont have enough in the clip left to stop your wild diving hail mary attempt to be the last man standing!
There are currently 5 classes in the game, each one simple to learn yet tough to master and all quite different from one another, the art design is great, equal parts quirky and badass!
The only gripe I have about the state of the game is it's current lack of players, finding a steady stream of opponents in prime time works out fine, but if you want to play at 2am it's just you and the tumble-weeds, but since it's early access it's nothing to set your watch to as more people start playing all the time and with incentives like the sale mentioned earlyer it's something I expect to be a thing of the past in no time!
I dont generally bother with early access games, believing them to ruin the awesome immersion a finished version of the game in question would provide were I not constantly telling myself well that'll be fixed in the full version and hopefully this and maybe that" but with gameplay this good
recommended: and a developer this dedicated Secret Ponchos is a can't miss!\n5/5"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Secret Ponchos is just THE RIGHT game for me, and it is extremely likely that you will LOVE IT too!

1. Idea and Delivery

Imagine yourself as Clint Eastwood walking into a deserted city in one of the movies in ‘The Man with No Name’ Trilogy by Sergio Leone. See yourself pulling a revolver and trying to aim at your opponent while he dashes to the side and tries to smoke you with a Molotov cocktail. Well, that is what Secret Ponchos is about.

The gameplay reminds me of the simpler times. Do you remember the sheer enjoyment of those good old Atari games that kept you glued to the screen for hours at a time? Secret Ponchos is a spirit child of those classic ancestors. It retains the intensity of engagement and simple but immersive mechanics.

3D cartoon graphics and subtle western instrumental in the background amplify the enjoyment of the game. Switchblademonkeys managed to produce a renaissance-like game by going back to the good old basics – fun experience, fair but unforgiving gameplay dynamics, with intense but humor-infused light-hearted competitive element. It is very likely that at some point it time, you will be blown to pieces by Kid Red at the last moment of a really tight match, while he simultaneously rubs it in – ‘TAKE THAT!’

2. Gameplay Dynamics

Secret Ponchos is game of dynamic paper-rock-scissors across 5 or 6 different dimensions – damage, moving speed, stamina, health, reload speed and range. Each character possesses some innate traits, two different weapons, and there is even a mini-element of RPG game allowing you to adjust the first 5 of 6 aforementioned characteristics.

The action is fast-paced and interactive. It amounts to tricking your opponent into making a mistake. You will need to anticipate your opponents’ move before making your own to be a great player at this game. In addition, you will need nimble fingers to sort through a variety of well-designed moves and combos each character has.

3. Depth, Versatility and Balance of Characters

In general, each character possesses two different weapons with at least two different types of attacks for each weapon. The depth and RPG element of the game, whereby you will be able to give a boost to some of your attributes as you gain experience, is perfectly suited for the ‘The God, The Bad and The Ugly’ type of confrontations. But do not be mistaken each attribute point will count. If you doubt me, play as Killer against Matador and adjust the speed attribute differently in each match.

Each character is unique and will provide a very different experience of the game and will require you to craft and use very distinct strategies in addressing various opponents. For example, a Killer has two weapons, revolver and a knife, which he can use in 4 standard and 1 three-part combo attacks. Each attack has unique characteristics and provides plenty of debt to serve most of the matches that will rarely exceed 5-7 minute timeframe.

Some characters will be harder to play than others, but no character will turn a bad player into a good one or a good player into a bad one. Imagine that you are playing pool and someone gives you a slightly better cue. You may sink few more shots but you will still be unable to play in the top league.

4. Community

I do not think that this review would be complete without mentioning the incredibly supportive Secret Ponchos community. My interaction with them began when I emailed SwitchBladeMonkeys on February 13, 2015 and received a reply from Yousuf Mapara the very same day. SBM team is effectively smaller than a dozen of people. The amount of commitment they showed to the players is incredible. Join the PC game chat and see for yourself. You can see them on a Twitch each Saturday morning as well.

5. Post-Game Experience

This is a category I don’t see but I think it should be included in game reviews.

Remember that feeling you had when playing Diablo for 8-hours straight, just repetitively left and right-clicking the screen in hope that you will be the lucky one bestowed with a legendary item drop. Remember that absurd, tired and angry feeling that overwhelmed you when you finally managed to turn off the computer and ask yourself – ‘What have I done with my day?’

Secret Ponchos is a game that will never make you feel that way. You will be able to play short, fun, engaging and interactive matches. Personally, I can’t spend hours on gaming. However, that doesn’t prevent me from enjoying this game to the fullest. I can play for 15-20 minutes at a time, put it aside, have a dinner with my wife or entertain guests shortly after without feeling exhausted.

6. Price – At 16.99 for one or 49.99 for a pack of four games this is one of the most affordable games with incredible replay value on the market. Enough said!

I hope you liked the review and I also hope to see you on the other side of the Saloon – colt and I will be waiting! I also can’t wait to try the new characters – Warmonger, Mad Trapper, and Gunman.

P.S. I would like to apologize, this was a lengthy post.

P.P.S. I base my feedback on the following experience in the game, which I started playing in January 2015:

Killer – 974 matches; 2,293 kills; 272K in bounty (106K deathmatch; 272K domination);
Hunter – 131 matches; 401 kills; 51K in bounty;
Kid Red – 57 matches; 219 kills; 27K in bounty;
Gordo – 22 matches; 90 kills; 10K in bounty;
