reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Game-
The gameplay is a blast! You actually feel like you’re wielding a six shooter. You dodge role and hide behind cover while reloading. It gets really intense, because aside from one character, there is no healing. It’s this constant tension between wanting to do damage while not taking damage.

It takes skill and teamwork.

The art and music are perfect for the game! The atmosphere is extremely well done.

The game has 10 fun, unique characters who each have their own skills and abilities. Once you get good enough you can even pull off some rewarding combos too!

There are 3 game modes right now.
Deathmatch- Stay alive, because you only get one life per round. (Best 2 out of 3)
Domination-  Kind of a “tug of war” for kills. First team to get 5 more kills then the other wins. (Or team with the highest score once time is up)
Posse Leader- 1 player per team is the “VIP” don’t let him die! The more kills the VIP gets the stronger he becomes! (Best 2 out of 3 rounds)

The Community-
The Community is great! If you ever need a hand they always try to help teach you the ropes.

The Devs-
The Devs are fantastic! You will never play any other game and be this much in contact with the Devs. They do a twitch stream every Saturday and you can usually find them in the steam group chat as well. They’ve put a lot of care into this game.

reviewText:
Pros -
Great Concept
Great Art
Good Controls (using 360 controller)

Cons -
Strange Menus
Poor Balance
Poor matchmaking
Terrible Latency Handling
Crashes Randomly
Glitchy Graphics/Gameplay


Whilst conceptually cool - and I'm sure I'll get something out of the single player arcade mode - the main draw is the online PvP Element which, sadly, is this game's weakest and ultimately renders it unredeemable.

There are good things about the game but I'm not really going to talk about them since proportionately they are worthless. I mean look at the trailer, it looks awesome... right?

After 7 hours I'm pretty confident in my understanding of the failures of the online modes.
Core Game:
So there are 10ish, very unique, classes in a twin stick shooter with moba elements, game modes that pit 1v1, 2v2 and 3v3 in 6 or 7 different maps. In online mode you have a selection of characters. Characters are built from the base classes, and have rpg-esque attribute points that can be spent as the player wishes, as the player wins with the character the character gains xp in the form of Bounty." At certain intervals you go up a rank and are given 2 more attribute points to spend on that character. This means more played with characters are also more powerful. Shouldn't cause problems except...

Matchmaking:
Matchmaking sucks. Where I am (the UK)
date: in ranked mode I'm very often (80%) matched with way higher level players
recommended: even this wouldn't be a problem except that you are penalised for it. Your character loses Bounty
hoursPlayed: even though its going up against players several ranks higher than you. For example my rank 3 character went up against a top rank player
voteText: I had about 2
helpfulPercent: 500 bounty
votesHelpful: they had over 100
votesFunny: this means also about 14 more attribute points (to my 6)
commentsCount: and presumably more than the few days the game has been out experience (great job early access)
column17: and in total dealing half the damage they dealt to me back at them
column18:
I lost Bounty. How does that make sense?

Balance:
So here is a weird quirk with the matchmaking
column19: when you play as some classes that have a high "difficulty" stat
column22: in the 2v2 matches I played about 80% of them would feature 1 or 2 more of the exact same character. So 3/4 would be The Wolf or the Killer
column23: I feel this speaks to the developers understanding of how imbalanced the characters actually are
column24: they try to circumvent that problem by not matching them up. There are just some classes that can't compete with others. You can tell in the practice mode by how easy it is to kill some characters
column25:
and how easy you die when you switch to them.

But these are only criticisms when the game works as it should:
The latency handling is terrible
column26: it is noticeably harder to play a game with players who have bad connections
column27: to the point that I could predict a poor match by just looking at their connection status
column28: regardless of my rank advantage. This latency manifests as being shot by bullets several times out of the range of the character
column29: almost never being able to hit the laggy player and classic warping (of them) across the level.\n\nIn my session today
column30: the game crashed 5 times and sometimes would lose Bounty for that.\nThe Wolf character's line of sights were crazy unstable
column31: sometimes they wouldn't appear but you could still fire
column32: other times your character does the animation of pulling a bow
column33: but releasing the trigger does nothing.\n\nFinally the frustrating menus
column34: there are too many boring and over repeated animations that make things like changing your character a chore
column35: or just getting to the next game. You can't even cancel joining a new game before you have joined it. You have to wait to join
column36: which would be slightly less upsetting if finding a game didn't sometimes take several minutes.  But sometimes you join a game past the point you can leave at all (even thought it hasn't started yet)
column37: and have to play a whole game or lose some bounty.\n\nSo I definitely cannot recommend this game
column38: as I have confidence in neither the design of the game or the execution. I'm frustrated that this game has been played so long
column39: making it less accessible to new players (days after its official release)."

reviewText:
Ok... i've been following this game since it was announced but didn't buy it because i'm a cheap person.
Well... this game is great...
Pros:
Fun combat. And that's something strange for me to say. Normally i get bored in a few minutes... This, i really like, when i saw the game i thought: ohh it's another smash the keyboard isometric game. Well, nope. It requieres for you to think about what to do. You have 2 weapons or a main weapon and an accessory that changes depending of the character you're using (dynamite, a medkit, a critical enhancing badge (yes.. weird), a knife, a lasso, molotvs, etc). You also have at least 2 styles of using your main weapon that can inflict status (like wonded, reducing movement speed, or blindness. You also have a stamina bar that allows you to dash and make melee attacks (if you choose a melee oriented class). Aiming is quite difficult in the good way, gamepads respond perfectly but you really have to aim or you won't hit... So it's all about timing and resourcces, running out of stamina, bad timing, not looking at the map. It's a really good game that mixes skill, strategy and knowing your opponents... To me, fun factor is 9/10. Every character feels different, so you can play in various styles.
Characters: there are about 10 right now. Everyone is different in playing styles. And i found everyone (but the tipical obese/nasty one, for now) being really fun. Normally i go one character and i'm done... here i'm playing with everyone online . I like that they stayed in stereotypes but they didn't at the same time. You have the characters you thought you would... but their designs are interesting. There's not the lawful sheriff or the big bad guy, they're all... normal... excentric characters... I love them all... But again, since i like them all, i would like to have more so...8/10 (skins are too expensive).
Music: Great, i didn't mute it... that's saying a lot. I normally play while watching something on the other monitor... Well, nope, i like it, but to be honest you eventually can get tired. Also, i don't remember any song but the title screen one.. so 7/10
Art style: i LOVE it, 10/10. it's that simple. I'd like more creativity in some characters (again, big ugly guy again)
Balance: Well, here's something odd. I was playing a match thinking: ITS IMPOSSIBLE, THE SNIPER IS TOO STRONG... then i played with it and i found that the trap-ster kicks it's ♥♥♥... But the rogue-speed guy defeats him (well, in a rocks paper scissor style, it doesnt mean you will win with him, you'll have more chances). So, there's balance issues in 1 vs 1... 2 vs 2 thing changes. Example, we were playing 2 vs 2 and we were two ghost ponchos (low range+dashes) against a bowgirl and a trickster (2 with the most range of the game) Impossible to attack them before being shot in the face. Eventually we found openings and made a strategy, without talking, without ... nothing, just by playing and syncing, and that happened lot of times... strategy becomes that intuitive. It really REALLY becomes a team game where you can work as a team, it's not about a guy sniping and killing everyone, it's about aiding each other. So... balance wise, it's balanced yet it's not... 2 vs 2 yes, 1 vs 1 ... not a lot...... 7/10
Matchmaking: I'm from south america... I had it for a few days, i managed to find about 10 people online (i think it's regional matchmaking). I wouldn't say the game is dead, but it could use a boost. Also, it kicks you from matchmaking if you've been waiting for too long... so if you're 3 waiting for the 4th player the room could dissolve. BUT, matchmaking, when there's people works like a charm. IT's -> click -> you're in the game. No waiting at all. Also, i'm from south... again... my ping isn't the best with ANYONE, and i can feel lag sometimes, still when i'm hit i cant curse a lot because i knew i was going to be hit. I have to lower the score because im from a third world country and no one buys games here so i'm alone like every valentine's day 6/10

Overall... i love this game... It's great. It would be awesome if the matchmaking worked a little better for me...
9/10.

reviewText: What can I even say about Secret Ponchos? As a Texan born and raised on Spaghetti Westerns and who was also named after John Wayne characters this game really strikes at the heart with me. So much nostalgia strikes and the soundtrack makes me want to listen to country ballads. But beyond all that heartwarming nonsense there is a very well made and engaging game here. All the characters have a strong sense of individuality with their own playstyles to boot. The gunplay is inuitive and fun and all the maps provide a fresh place for strategy. I feel as though this game has a strong amount of potential and its current community is simply thriving with closeness and determination.\n\nIn conclusion, this game is well worth your money. With that I have no doubt. So throw your hat on and strap that big iron to your hip. There is a storm brewing in lonetree and everyone is invited.

reviewText:
This game is great, but it needs a major optimization. That is not a concern of yours if you have a gaming pc. but the system requirement is too high for that kind of game.

The worst part is that there are only 3 settings in the graphic options. The lowest setting doesn't remove shadows (they claim they do, but a few people still have shadows even on low setting).

That being said, do I recommend it or not?.. Yes.. the devs are super helpful. They helped me more than once and are dedicated to their game. The game have some problems, but I have no doubt that they will make it better,

reviewText:
I have been following Secret Ponchos since it was announced and it has been on my wishlist forever now. I am really glad I got to play it during the free week. Secret Ponchos is a game I plan on purchasing in the future, as I have come to really enjoy it.

In Secret Ponchos you play as a criminal of some sort racking up a bounty by defeating other players in multiplayer. While there is single player arcade and practice modes the real focus is on the multiplayer side of things.  There are 10 playable character classes currently, each one with its own unique weapons and play style. There are multiple skins for some characters, and character stats are tweakable with stat points through the customization menu.

The actual gameplay revolves around running around a variety of maps, solo or in your posse" battling it out with enemy gangs in the wild west. There are a good deal of maps to play on
date: and a only few different game modes I have experienced including "one life" round based survival game mode

reviewText:
I have been following Secret Ponchos since it was announced and it has been on my wishlist forever now. I am really glad I got to play it during the free week. Secret Ponchos is a game I plan on purchasing in the future, as I have come to really enjoy it.

In Secret Ponchos you play as a criminal of some sort racking up a bounty by defeating other players in multiplayer. While there is single player arcade and practice modes the real focus is on the multiplayer side of things.  There are 10 playable character classes currently, each one with its own unique weapons and play style. There are multiple skins for some characters, and character stats are tweakable with stat points through the customization menu.

The actual gameplay revolves around running around a variety of maps, solo or in your posse" battling it out with enemy gangs in the wild west. There are a good deal of maps to play on

reviewText:
--The PROS--

The gameplay is a fast, action packed romp. Once you get the hang of the controls, you'll really feel like you're in a wild west shootout. There's nothing quite like ducking for cover just in time to miss a shotgun blast, or making a sudden dive and wheeling around just in time to blow away your foe. The interactivity with the environment is great, and adds an extra layer to the action.

The aesthetic of the game is fantastic. The music has the perfect mix of compelling western flair with just enough modern spice. The characters are vibrant and evocative, as are the locales. The SFX are solid too; landing the final shot that ends a tough duel sounds as good as it feels.

--The CONS--
The game's single-player options are very limited. This is effectively an online multiplayer game only. Indeed, it feels like the multiplayer options also have a lot of room for expansion (4v4 or 5v5, more maps and modes). The game takes some getting used to, and the tutorial does a mediocre job of preparing the player (definitely will need to play a few real rounds before you really get it). Also, there are the occasional bugs in the menu and matchmaking that can be an inconvenience (though they're not really significant).

Secret Ponchos is a short shot of frenetic fun. I definitely recommend checking it out, especially now while it's on free week and on sale.

reviewText:
I thought the name was silly, but I couldn't turn down a free weekend of it.

Now I own it.

I love the art style, the music, and the gameplay and balance is stellar. You have different characters to choose and fighting goes far beyond right click aim left click shoot": Each has a "move" list like you'd see in a fighting game like Tekken or something that allows you to do all sorts of neat crap on top of pumping other gangsters full of lead. It's a game that just takes raw skill
date: but there's no reason to be intimidated: It's an easy-to-learn-but-hard-to-master sort of game. Note that the different characters also have "Difficulty" ratings and there are plenty that are welcoming to new players (And seriously
recommended: none of them are overpowered. More often than not low difficulty characters tend to be irritatingly common to find and hard to beat
hoursPlayed: but that's not the case here) and man this game is just fun. I highly reccommend it on sale and it's definitely worth it at full price."

reviewText:
As much as I suck at video games, this one is pretty accomodating to new players. The tutorial is nice, and the learning curve is quite reasonable. It's really easy to just go into the game and start playing. Even if you only know the very basics of the game, you're still guaranteed to have a blast, just as I did. That said, there's alway more to learn and improve on, so the gameplay never feels stale, and every play that you pull off feels immensely rewarding, since everything is a skillshot, and there's always a cost to using any ability. I'm honestly blown away by how much fun I've been having. A friend of mine recommended this game really highly to me, and I like it way more that I thought I would. Even so, I did recognize that this game has a pretty small playerbase...


But we can easily fix that by getting more people to play with us!


Buy this game. I promise you won't regret it.


Stay classy, outlaws. <3

reviewText:
A rare gem in a sea of endless inde junk, secret ponchos is a great game with a great concept.  While it could be classified as a MOBA, I really dont think of it as one because of several things that seperate it from other mobas. For one, it requires more skill than other mobas, since your attacks don't lock on to your targets and Movement is much more important. It also doesnt have a shop, towers, lanes, minions, or any of that.
While a simple game on the surface, it is suprisingly hard, with a high skill ceiling. I would recomend looking at some guides before you hop in and use practice mode to get a good feel for your characters against AI bots.
The only negatives are the occasional bug and balancing issue, but they rarely get in the way of the gameplay.

Overall, a original, great game (with a great community as well) and a few problems gives this game a solid 8.5/10.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is easily one of my top indie games. I recommend it to people who enjoy a game that can pick up and play with ease. The game definitely falls under the category of 'easy to learn, hard to master', as the kits of the Outlaws (champs) are reletively simple at face value.

Pros
- lovely art
-competitive gameplay
-great music
-fun in 20 minute intervals, fun in 4 hour interevals... it's fun
-with different team comps, brings totally different playstyle for teams. With 10 differnt Outlaws, there are a LOT of team comps
-enough maps to keep gameplay from becoming stale

Cons
-small community makes for some long Queue times

Overall this game is fantastic. Once the community begins to grow, I believe it will become a game I will play for years to come. This game has mechanics that I think rival some triple A games. If you're thinking about getting this game, I absolutely think you should, however... Be patient, game communities do not grow overnight. A game with such great mechanice WILL gain in playerbase, it just take a bit of time.

Early Access Review

Secret Ponchos is a spaghetti western themed battle arena where players team up to murder one another.

The character models are gorgeous, the maps are animated, sweet-looking, and feature destructible assets, and the game modes are quick and dirty.

Everyone knows about Deathmatch, but Secret Ponchos' true power lies in Domination, which is Deathmatch with an added kick.  In Domination, you compete to move a kill marker to your side.  Each kill moves your marker closer to your victory.  Of course, the enemy team is doing the same, so it's quite the fight.

Your ranks are stored per character, so while I may have Kid Red ranked up a few times (with obligatory stat point investiture) my rank with The Killer remains at 0 - so you have to use each Outlaw if you really want to have a full arsenal of options - but if you like your character and don't want to change, then there's no reason to, since you're not hurting yourself in any way.

The battles are fast and fierce, and you aren't extremely durable, so you're always wondering if the next fracas will be your last.

It's a game that absolutely MUST be played.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Positive:
For an online game with a small community, the community is pretty dang good.
Despite the amount of players that play at any given time I still reccommend this game, just because the community feels so close knit, and nice.
If you do get this game I reccomend going to their steam page, and joining the chat, it's the best way to get into a match, you do need to pick the times you play, but I'd say it's well worth it.

On top of the positive direction the community is heading, you can tell the Devs are really trying to make the game as good as possible. You will see alot of them in chat playing and talking with the players, and are very welcoming to new comers.

Negative:
There are a few bugs, and balancing issues (it feels like, only a couple hours played so far) which I came into the game expecting, however the only major one that hinder gameplay was the server stability. Perhaps it was just me, but occassionally players would jump around, despite this lag issue, it didn't ever feel like I was being cheated by it.
Players who hate latency issues may want to wait a little while, I'm sure they will patch the problems soon enough though.
The only other bug that was a nuisance was the occassional crash.

Worth?:
In it's current stage I actually reccommend, the game is only going to get better, and the community is quite a nice bunch. However if you get this game, and ignore the community, at its current stage you might not get where I think alot of the enjoyment comes from.

SO TL;DR
IF YOU GET THIS GAME, COME JOIN THE COMMUNITY ON THE STORE PAGE, OR YOU ARE MISSING OUT ALOT. JOOOIINN UUSSSS <3

reviewText:
First impression of Secret Ponchos is very positive. Each mode is 1v1 2v2 or 3v3 where each player chooses their outlaw, all with their own unique brand of main weapon, secondary, and style.

There's something really thrilling, and exciting about huddling behind an abandoned wagon as you wait for your opponent to hop into a false sense of security, or timing your shots so you don't accidently wound an ally. Reloading feels tense, alarming of when is a good time. Wanting to make each shot count, else you find yourself open to pain.

The only few problems I encountered were very minor. On ocassion, the game would spike with some lag, making certain attacks miss which otherwise would hit, or vise versa and some of the menu navigation doesn't work with mouse controls.

This game truly, desperately needs more attention then it's mustered since it's release. It's a charming, little title with a gorgeous aesthetic, easy to learn, difficult to master skill ceiling. I, wish the devs all the luck in the world helping the community grow and I can't wait to be a part of it as it does.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
TL;DR game is fun, the package it comes in... ehhh...

This game is fast paced yet precise with a range of characters and some creative (if annoying) maps, it has great mechanical depth and scope for awesome gun duels and team play. I very much enjoyed my time dueling my friends.
I WOULD recommend this game, HOWEVER there are just one too many negative aspects which make means I would only recommend it if you are prepared to deal with these annoying issues:

-Menu system/lobbies are absolute garbage:
to make a new character you have to backtrack out of your team's/friend's lobby to the main menu and then navigate to the online lobby and find the option that lets you make a character.
Everything is hidden away in random menus and nothing is intuitive untill you have learnt how to navigate them.

-Matchmaking: (particuarly with friends)
If you want to play online with your friends you are going to have to be prepared for a lot of hassle and long waits. Very occasionaly it will work first time and you will get straight into a game, most of the time however when you try and invite your friends it wont let them join or it will refuse to find any other players to match you with. Often to fix this you have to leave and rejoin multiple times.
This is made even more annoying by the fact the game is incredibly fast paced. Deathmatches can be over in minutes meaning that you often spend a lot longer waiting to play the game than actually playing the game.
EDIT: the issue with friends being broken up has been fixed according to the devs, however the waiting time can still be lenghty even when playing by yourself or doing 1v1s due to not enough players/ inneficient matchmaking.

-Bugs:
You will probably notice a few weird bugs whilst playing. It is possible to clip edges if you are dodging around too much and the line of sight mechanic can sometimes bug out meaning you can see/be seen by players in situations that shouldn't allow it. Also some characters have very weird hitboxes with some of their ranged attacks and it is obvious that more time has been put into making and polishing some characters over others. Although these bugs are to be honest very minor and really not too much of an issue (despite showing an obvious lack of polish) since the games are so fast paced as I mentioned earlier one small glith can mean you lose a trade and therefore lose the game.

So to conclude:
I wouldn't buy this game at full price for sure, on a decent sale however it might be a great pick up and definitely good value. There are a lot of frustrating elements that detract from the actual game itself and overall force me to give this game a nevagive review, however as many other reviews talk about the meat of the game itself is very fun so if you enjoy MOBAs or bullet hell games and you have some friends to play with go ahead and get this game. But be warned, in its current state it might annoy you more than you enjoy it.

reviewText:
Pros:
+ character variety with every one being truly different not only in stats, but in roles they play in the team
+ heavily skill-based, and even though it has some progression, it is minor, so fresh players still are quite able to compete even when facing a more leveled player
+ quite accurate matchmaking, especially in SoloQ, and even if you do run into someone with higher bounty (elo), you get a compensation for it and vice versa
+ perfomance is not an issue at all, never seen a frame drop
+ amazing development crew, actually talking to players in chat, at a constant basis
+ no microtransactions at all, the only thing you can buy extra, atm, is a skin pack, which obviously confers no in-game bonuses
Cons:
- lacks some chat features at the moment, but those are going to be added this week
- lacking proper video settings menu, but it automatically does detect your resolution with no problems, so for most people it should be fine
- sometimes matches may be laggy due to high ping of either party, but again, mostly not an issue

r8 88/8, must buy if you're into competitive arena games like quake and western-theme stuff

reviewText:
I played 5 matches my first night to try this game out. 3 of those matches crashed mid-game and required me to use task manager to close the game. It also inexplicably makes other programs running on my PC crash as well, such as Firefox if I have both open at the same time.

The leveling up system is also meaningless, as you get nothing for leveling up. No extra skill points, no new weapons no skills, nothing. Your level seems to only affects the skill of the people you fight against, and leaving or having a match crash takes an extreme amount of xp away from you.

The good news though? You can just leave games constantly to stay at level 1, if you want to curb stomp noobs all day.

I wont be buying this game, its a buggy mess with no meaningful progression.
voteText: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
I got the game during the free week, and I really want to like it, but I can't. It is still too unpolished for me to enjoy and recommend it. As an Early Access, this would get a solid 9/10 from me, but as a game that's being presented as a final product, I can't give it such a high score.

Some game mechanics are unbalanced and bugged (like The Killer's knife, which can fly over a cover and hit a target hiding behind that cover, or Phantom's whip, that can be seen by opponent even without clear visual on covering Phantom, therefore rendering any cover for sneaking totally useless with whip equipped), there are typos and misspelling in achievements and moveset descriptions, hitboxes sometimes behave way too odd, and connecting to a match (even if we don't count the matchmaking system, which is sometimes quite unballanced) is a pain in about one fifth of all 1v1 cases - if the opponent doesn't load the match, you get stuck on the match loading screen (which is just a blank screen with crow wallpaper - no indication if you are still loading or waiting for an opponent). The only way out is to force quit the game, which then causes a -300 $ Bounty drop every time.

This game certainly got my attention and I will definitely consider purchasing it in the future, if the issues will get solved. The atmosphere of spaghetti westerns, the music, the design and both single and multiplayer gameplay (if we ignore all the negative stuff I wrote above) are quite good and original. However at this state, I'm not going to spend my money on a product that needs fixing.

reviewText:
An interesting game.

The previews emphasize there is a high skill ceiling.

This might be true, however, with such a small player base, that means climbing the ladder will be difficult. Playing the free weekend I had fun intially however I eventually hit the wall" of the veterans.

I am used to climbing walls. I have played Dwarf fortress. However even Dwarf fortress has the virtue of allowing learning of mistakes via saves if so wish. Not so naturally with a multiplayer games.

If you enjoy climbing walls in a multiplayer sense then this is a great game. However if you don't enjoy the process then this is not the game for you.

I had a fun few hours
date: but I see I have met my match. I really wish there was a "neutral" button but there is not. So if I was forced to choose...\n\nI would tell my friends to pick a larger game
recommended: so there was a more gradual skill ladder"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Firstly - the art style is fan-flipping-tastic. Everything about Secret Ponchos feels really fresh and unique. I'll have to review again once I've spent more time in it, but my first impressions are great.  Each character has a unique loadout which provide more than just range/damage/speed differences, but in some cases completely alter the way you play the game. There's  a really slick level of polish to areas of the game that make it a joy to play. From the way the whip trails after you on the Phantom Poncho, the gorgeous poses and animations of every character, to the responsiveness of the controls and abilities. I'd definitely say some characters are much easier to pick up than others. Within a few minutes of playing Phantom - landing a stun with his long range whip, diving in close and quick-switching to his short range double barrel felt really great,  Where as other characters, such as the matador have some extra layers of depth in the learning, and most certainly the mastering phases.

Obviously it's early access, so there's a miriad of areas for improvement that, with the active and involved devs, seem like extra layers of polish just waiting to happen.  There's nothing that really stands out as game-breaking" or annoying in the gameplay right now. Once you're playing it feels fluid and seamless
date: and the strategic aiming /range mechanics mixed with the fast-twitch FPS feel is a ton of fun. I would 100% recommend picking up the game with a bunch of friends and dueling it out Secret Ponchos style!\n"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is like a PvP, multiplayer version of a modern version of the stand up arcade game Gunsmoke the 80's which is awesome, because I love the Western theme.  It's also great, because Western themed games aren't as common vs. say modern or futuristic games.

Although PvP type games aren't my first choice,  I think PvP fanatics will love this game.  The matches are nice and quick and there is good flow between the matches.

Graphics are good and I have no issues playing at full resolution and max details on my laptop (Nvidia GTX850m) or on my desktop (Radeon HD 7970).

Most importantly, the devs have been on top of listening to the feedback and appear to be constantly improving and adding to the game which is a huge plus. Much <3 to the Indie devs / little guys!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is such a piece of gem that hasn't been discovered by steam and PC users. I've only played it a couple times when it wasn't even support mouse in this game. But still, the game experience attracted me to wait for its development and the release of its full potential. The only problem this game is facing is not having too many players at the moment. This doesn't mean that the game is dead since it also runs on consoles. Plus, I've contacted the development team and they told me that the game is about to be fully launched into steam, which means a huge boost of population coming soon.

When the game gets out of early access, this is definitely a worthy buy if the population of the game can maintain at a stable amount. The combat system and the graphics are very good, style of the game is nice and etc. Only one thing I've not that satisfied was there's only 2v2 available. But I believe they will put more modes into the game.

reviewText:
Very fun pvp game with a nice Italo- Western scenario and suiting soundtracks.

It offers different multiplayer modes like 3 VS 3 domination or ranked matches.
You either can meet your friends ingame or match with random people.
There is also a mode you can play with the AI to improve your skills.

The charakters are very fun to play since they all have different abilities, strengths and weaknesses you will figure out.
Some are harder to master than others.

The game would have looked a bit nicer in a third person view and not from the top down camera angle but thats my opinion.

The only downer so far is that you cannot increase the performance too much because the graphic settings are very limited. However the good news are that developers already confirmed to work on this issue.

10th December 2015 Edit: Thanks to the great support, the game now has already got a patch that included the option to turn of shadows etc and even weaker pcs might now get a more steady framerate. Now only the ability to change the resolution to a lower one while still beeing able to play fullscreen is missing.

If you like the setting and an arena shooter where you need much skill you should definately try this one out.

reviewText:
So you are debating Secret Ponchos...

Do yourself a favor... BUY. THIS. GAME.

Not only is this one of the most intense, strategic, mechanically adept games you probably will ever play; it's also one of the most detailed twists on the current day MOBA" out there.

Think of the game as a mix between League of Legends and WoW Arena pvp.

You get to choose a preset character (which you can customize with skins and different stats) but then are thrown into fast paced
date: strategy based combat similar to WoW arena pvp. You have the ability to dodge abilities
recommended: each character has special "moves" and the amount of skill varies per character.\n\nThe devs are some of the most humble and involved devs I've ever met. They're always in chat
hoursPlayed: always working on the game and are beyond eager to make this the most perfect creation on Steam.\n\nNot only is the name Secret Ponchos 12/3 IGN confirmed kek worthy
voteText: but the game is a work of art.\n\nIn conclusion

reviewText:
Secret Ponchos is a very skill based game.

Charge in and you die.

Take too long to make a move, get surround and you die.

Waste all your ammo and dashes, unable to  perform and you die.

A good amount of characters that have multiple ways of attacking.

Game is balanced, for now. Although, some characters when matched with other characters can make a horrible team (Deserter and Trapper) (although both heroes are good, if used right.)

Buy the game and play it, if you like a challenge

reviewText: This is the first time I write a review for a game and there's a reason Secret Ponchos is deserving of this honor. This game is not just good, it's crazy good. The gameplay is fast and extremely addictive (in a good way, you'll just want to rematch those a****** that just beat you). I would recommend it to anyone who like competitive pvp action, it's 100% based on skills and (thank god) it's absolutely not pay to win. Most of the negative reviews I've read so far are bout the menu (with the no mouse support) or the ranking and skill points system. This brings me to the second great quality of this game, the devs are actually listening. They want players to enjoy their game and they work hard in that way. Already they announced a patch for the skill points, less than 10 days after the official release. I love this game, I really do and I think it needs to be promoted to increase its population. The game deserve it. How much money many of you guys put in CoD franchise? This is only $17 (CDN) and its worth every penny (unlike CoD).

reviewText:
What an amazingly simple, addictive and engaging game!

Secret Ponchos is a breath of fresh air in an increasing stale team competition environment that, for the most part, emphasizes the importance of gear, stats, builds and cookie-cutter strategies. Matchmaking is easy. The characters are quirky, and they appeal to a broad range of play styles. And small elements of the MOBA format are blended seemlessly with fast-paced isometric twitch shooting in such a way as to not be overbearing, complicated or inaccessible. Secret Ponchos is casual good times, and its community is a friendly, fun-loving one. The $9.99 customization DLC is well worth it too. Bombed-out Kid Red is pure hilarious eye candy.

I can't reccomend it enough. In fact, Secret Ponchos is so damn good that I actually bothered to write a Steam review of it. Buy it. Lose yourself in it. Enjoy a well-earned break from organizing stacks of building materials and consumables in the rushed-out early access survival game you are currently playing and are no doubt already getting sick to death of.

reviewText:
Please try it on the free week. I can definitely see the appeal for this game.

Learning curve is pretty insane, large amount of skill required, no remorse for anyone that wants to play more casually, and kinda unbalanced classes. I can go on for more but it honestly gets down to nit picks at the point.

I can see the appeal for highly skilled players but for the other majority you're probably just going to get pub stomped or carried. The little time I played there was only one close match and that was pretty fun ended up losing but at least everyone on both teams actually got several kills. I think the main problem with the game is there is only small games (1v1 or 3v3) I think it could benefit from larger games, anywhere from 5v5 to 8v8. Or even possibly pub vs bots. I honestly kinda doubt it'll have players after long since it being really unforgiving for new players/less skillfull players. It's not a bad game by any means, just I can't see allot of people really getting into it.

TL;DR: Not a bad game but if your bad at the game it'll suck horribly, and I'm bad at the game.

If its no longer the free week get it when its less then or 10$.


Amazing art style though.

reviewText:
{EDIT 1]: The dev commented this post, which I think is really neat. Devs definetly support the game and don't abandon it, which is a good sign!

Okay, it's 3.45 am (GMT +1; in the night/morning) and I really looked forward playing this game. I bought it in the HumbleBundle and the trailers and reviews looked really promising. And to be honest? This game is great. Really great actually. The gameplay itself is a top down shooter but in a MOBA themed arena - 2vs2. You choose a character, add a few stats and that is it - you are good to go! Well..no, unfortunately. Why? Because no one seems to be playing the game. Seriously! I was waiting for a few minutes in a lobby, until 2 more people joined. The last and 4th person didn't join after a while, so I left and tried again a few minutes later, after I played a round with the AI. What happened? The same two people.
To sum it all up - great game, no players though.

reviewText:
What should you expect?Cartoony, multiplayer-only twin-stick shooter in which your only goal is to gun down the other players in a Western environement.

The good+Strategic gunplay
+Various character types to chose from
+Enjoyably fast-paced
+Character progression brings high replay value
+Cover system implemented during fights
+Waiting for games is quite short, max 1-2minutes

The bad-No single player, no story behind the game
-Few maps to chose from
-Limited modes without any innovation (pretty much it's Deathmatch..and others)


Verdict
It's an enjoyable game, with a fair price, that will make you spend many hours trying to improve your bandit. It's worth buying and it delivers what it says.

7.5/10

P.S. I'm looking forward to see if there will be updates or even a single player story mode.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Secret Ponchos is a competitive twin-stick shoot-out fest with MOBA styling’s set in taking in an isometric Old West world.

Pick a miscreant from four characters, partner up with another player to create a gang, albeit a small one, then head out to the digital frontier to find another like-minded couple and do them more harm than they can do to you in the time that’s allowed.

The game plays much like an online battle arena title as the classes selected play an important part of the game. Each of the characters posse has a unique trait, weapon and play-style. The four currently available are: ‘The Killer‘; a balanced all-rounder with medium range and movement speed with a six shooter and a throwing knife. ‘Kid Red‘; who’s a quick lad but deals light damage however does have a mean arm to throw sticks of TNT! ‘The Deserter‘ has better range, but slower rate of fire/movement but carries a deployable medic bag, then finally the ‘The Phantom Poncho‘. The mysterious Phantom uses a double barrel shotgun and is a lethal whip wielder able to stun at a good range.


Like Team Fortress 2 (a game the developers have stated as an influence), the title plays the most fun when understanding your buddies and baddies abilities because working effectively with your cohort will win the duel-duel (double-duel?). Playing as the ‘Phantom Poncho’ for example you’re able to use your whip to snare or stun the enemy while a ‘Deserter’ class can then impale an opponent dealing an impressive 1-2 of massive damage. This is not a game to play lone wolf – unless the match making is broken …which it is from time-to-time.

On the subject of bugs the game is still in it’s “Early Access” cycle so as you would expect it has some stability issues and as well as absent features. The game will crash out from time-to-time or you’ll encounter ‘quirks’ – such as if you’re in the lobby on your own you can force the match to start with just your character leaving you to wonder the badlands on your lonesome.

Three maps are available to duke it out in. This is quite a small amount, but each does offer a different scale, style and are well crafted enough to allow for plenty of choke points or spots to hide and ambush an opponent using the cover, such as behind barrels and walls. These items are however destructible so you do have to pick and choose your hideout wisely. Although a player’s health doesn’t regenerate, around the map, you’ll also have access to random pick-ups that spawn (along with other perks).

At the end of the round, doing well in a match allows you to level up and to increase a characters reputation/notoriety. This progression results in points to spend on boosting the base stats and abilities of your character (movement speed, fire rate etc).

The Good

Graphically Secret Ponchos is slick and polished. The characterisations are amazingly animated, look detailed and have a fun Gorillaz-esq style to them. Levels and environments are created with a lot of care and attention to detail. Touches like bottles on tables in the saloon can be shot/knocked are small, but add to the overall feel. Aurally the music is a real highlight with selection of distinctive western style melodies that are both catchy and memorable. The four characters are also well balanced towards each other and give a solid learning curve that when you proficient prove complementarily to your duelling partnership and to be feared.

Currently the game has no keyboard and mouse support, but thankfully the game works really well with a twin-stick controller (either Xbox 360 or DualShock game pads). Controls are responsive and layout is intuitive/easy to pick up and play after only a few minutes of game time.


The Bad

The biggest issue, and one I completely understand how it has occurred, is that the game doesn’t have enough bodies playing, making its matchmaking at ‘off-peak’ times decidedly difficult. When you do manage to play, the only team sizes are 2-vs-2 and in addition having only one flavour of game mode available, Domination, does tend to make things go stale shortly. Four playable characters and three maps, as wonderful as they are to play and look at, are too few to allow you to get stuck in or hold your attention for any duration. If you do wish to hone your skills away from real people, the offline practice mode consists of a measly match against constant respawning lifeless and stationary opponents. This brings us on to….

The Ugly

The unattractive truth is that Secret Ponchos is a toothless prospector; the game is missing a lot but knows where the gold is! Players will need to be patient before we can finally hit pay dirt.

Number 1 on the Wanted list has got to be increasing the team sizes. Four players (2 vs. 2) is simply not enough. Next new characters and game modes are also needed. Stable mates of any such game of this ilk should include free-for-all or even some sort of capture the flag/objectives are needed. The maps I also feel should be more interactive and have elements that can be used against your opponents – such as TNT crates that explode, or some sort of hunters traps that stun.

After this the top priority for the devs should be adding AI and then using them to craft s a singleplayer experience with a narrative (as these characters are crying out for a back story or an adventure) or even better still co-operative mode with you and a buddy, Butch and Sundance against the ‘horde’ of desperado’s.

Options are woefully missing from the menu for the basic and usual technical titbits you’d expect from a PC game. No interface exists for changing the screen resolution; this is instead managed via a keyboard combination, nor an option to even quit out of the game at the time of writing.

It appears although not implemented that eventually you’ll be able to see how you stack up against your internet brethren in official league tables. At the moment the Leaderboard to check your standings against other players, ‘Blood Bets’, gang management and an Online Store for what appears to be character customisation lead to nowhere.

Verdict

So what does the future hold for Secret Ponchos? Well although Switchblade Monkeys have confirmed very little of a development timeline, they have said that many of the wish list (maps, modes, AI and even split-screen etc) are coming to the game at launch. Two more characters are due. A lady Matador appears in promotional material who is seen to be lightning fast, but has to utilise melee attacks only, and the other being teased by the development team is a “Trapper” (whom I envisage as a brawler Davy Crocket type fellow) who they hint at will be able to lay suitable ambushes for other dastardly outlaw types. As well as new characters and more maps are mentioned throughout development and more post launch to expand the universe they’ve created.

Secret Ponchos is not a bad game. It’s not an overly buggy game. It’s just a very early release of something that could be amazing. For the money and its status I’m not expecting League of Legends or Team Fortress, but at this moment it just has too few ways for you to die in the Old West. The game is paper thin, but on that paper it has jotted down some good ideas, created some wonderfully presented art work and a detailed treasure map for its planned journey ahead.

Those that are keen to get in on the ground floor of a new game, work with the developers to find bugs and perfect character balance will be appreciated, however if you are looking for something you can get your teeth into you most definitely will want to wait.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While I think this game has spectacular potential I feel as though there were a few things that were not 'up to par' with current gaming standards. The gaming community is much too large for any game to create such a blatant gap in capability between those who have played a lot and those who have only just touched the game. After about an hour of game time I seem to be able to go toe-to-toe with anybody near my 'level'. However the damage numbers and stamina recharge time as a starting player is terribly inferior to those who have logged tons of game hours. Granted I understand you can reach those levels, but every time you lose a match, you also lose your cash. This is not the best system to draw in more players. And speaking of more players... this game needs it... bad. The que times and stat differences between players make for a very displeasing experience.

Despite all the bad the game really is pretty for what it is, and the characters are obviously thematic and not just copies of eachother. The gameplay is fun unless you find yourself trying to manage the cover mechanics. I'm sure volume control will come with the platform shift, but until then we'll have to struggle with frustrating volume and controllers.

All in all. Here's what I score it.

Art: 8/10
Gameplay: 7/10
Outlaw Balance: 4/10
Multiplayer Interraction: 2/10
Addicting: 7/10
Overall: 6.5/10

Worth the buy if on sale or if you have four friends who want to try something new. If you want a game that will entertain you for years, probably find something else. If you love westerns and 'P4WN1NG n00bz', then skip on a few spit shines on the way home from the bank and drop the current price of 15$ to enjoy something entertaining.

reviewText:
Not for me.

Hit boxes seem small, even for big fat characters.

Character designs are pretty cool, I really like them.  Some characters seem like they will be
overpowered versus others, have not played enough to say for sure, but I could see these ones being
exploitable.

I can't seem to hit anyone by aiming at them.  I have to aim at their feet to shoot them in the middle of
their body.  Normally in a game you aim at the chest or the head.  Here you have to point at their feet.
Perhaps this is a symptom of 2D gameplay with 3D presentation, but it's just not comfortable for me and
does not feel fun.  Do I get extra damage for a headshot?  Do I aim at the knees to hit the head?

Even the long range fighters can't shoot very far.  It looks like the fighters are 10-20 feet away from
each other when in range to shoot.  When you shoot beyond range, you cannot hit even if you're lined up
perfectly.  It's like a magic bullet eating forcefield eats your shot.  I get what they are trying to do
here, but the bullet was invented so you could put holes in things that are far away...and short of a
nerf gun, I don't know of any weapons that are ineffective at ten paces.  So it's too hard for me to
suspend disbelief here.

Everyone I fought took an insane amount of hits to kill.  If I'm this close, why can I empty all six
shots into the enemy from five feet away and still have to reload and hit them some more before they die?

The characters don't automatically reload when out of ammo...at least the red guy I played first didn't.
I found the best way to keep bullets in my guns was to tap R constantly.  It was too hard to do this and
move at the same time.  I could map the R to my StealthSwitch and spam tap it, but I don't think that
would be fun and I wish the game would auto reload when out like pretty much every FPS ever since the
ammo counter was added.  Hey, the arrow girl doesn't seem to run out of arrows.  Looks like I found
someone I like! heh

The hook here is that this is supposed to be skill based, and I see they did make some choices that
reflect that.  I didn't feel much like that was happening, more that I was learning the game's systems,
like shooting at feet and shooting only when in range.  There's a lot here to dig into with the different
characters, so I can see some people getting into it.  Unfortunately I like what they were trying to do
here a lot more than I like the result.

You only played 37 minutes.  You should play longer before your opinion is valid."
I didn't really want to play after this point.  The things that were bothering me from the start were
still bothering me in the second half hour
date: so that's when I stopped playing.  I can usually tell if I\nlike a game in the first ten minutes.  So anyone reading this can keep in mind these are my first\nimpressions

Not for me.

Hit boxes seem small, even for big fat characters.

Character designs are pretty cool, I really like them.  Some characters seem like they will be
overpowered versus others, have not played enough to say for sure, but I could see these ones being
exploitable.

I can't seem to hit anyone by aiming at them.  I have to aim at their feet to shoot them in the middle of
their body.  Normally in a game you aim at the chest or the head.  Here you have to point at their feet.
Perhaps this is a symptom of 2D gameplay with 3D presentation, but it's just not comfortable for me and
does not feel fun.  Do I get extra damage for a headshot?  Do I aim at the knees to hit the head?

Even the long range fighters can't shoot very far.  It looks like the fighters are 10-20 feet away from
each other when in range to shoot.  When you shoot beyond range, you cannot hit even if you're lined up
perfectly.  It's like a magic bullet eating forcefield eats your shot.  I get what they are trying to do
here, but the bullet was invented so you could put holes in things that are far away...and short of a
nerf gun, I don't know of any weapons that are ineffective at ten paces.  So it's too hard for me to
suspend disbelief here.

Everyone I fought took an insane amount of hits to kill.  If I'm this close, why can I empty all six
shots into the enemy from five feet away and still have to reload and hit them some more before they die?

The characters don't automatically reload when out of ammo...at least the red guy I played first didn't.
I found the best way to keep bullets in my guns was to tap R constantly.  It was too hard to do this and
move at the same time.  I could map the R to my StealthSwitch and spam tap it, but I don't think that
would be fun and I wish the game would auto reload when out like pretty much every FPS ever since the
ammo counter was added.  Hey, the arrow girl doesn't seem to run out of arrows.  Looks like I found
someone I like! heh

The hook here is that this is supposed to be skill based, and I see they did make some choices that
reflect that.  I didn't feel much like that was happening, more that I was learning the game's systems,
like shooting at feet and shooting only when in range.  There's a lot here to dig into with the different
characters, so I can see some people getting into it.  Unfortunately I like what they were trying to do
here a lot more than I like the result.

You only played 37 minutes.  You should play longer before your opinion is valid."
I didn't really want to play after this point.  The things that were bothering me from the start were
still bothering me in the second half hour
date: so that's when I stopped playing.  I can usually tell if I\nlike a game in the first ten minutes.  So anyone reading this can keep in mind these are my first\nimpressions

reviewText:
I'm going to keep it short because I don't want to waste anymore time on this game.

Pros:
-Unique concept
-Each character has unique game style
-Superior graphics and animations compared to other indie games

Cons:
-Horrible horrible P2P based net code. Laggers can warp and kill you even if they don't hit you in your screen. If you've played GunZ online you know what I am talking about.
-Has some bugs but they're mostly harmless except constant crashing
-Very low player base. If I can reach top 100 with my 31,7 hours of gameplay it tells that only about 100 people invest a lot of time into this game.
-Ranked leaderboard is TIME based. It rewards you for playing a lot of matches not for being good.


Soo.. outside of that devs are really nice and listen to community. The only downside is that they will probably never fix the net code. They've only said that they consider making regional locks but IT WILL NOT FIX THE LAG PROBLEM it only reduces the amount of laggers. Devs are also trying to make patches which make this more esport" like... nothing wrong with that but this game WILL NEVER BECOME ESPORT GAME because of that ♥♥♥♥♥♥ P2P client based net code.

Summary:
Buy the game only if you want to play against friends. Playing against random people just makes you to lose your nerves because eventually you'll run into laggers / bug abusers."

reviewText:
The game is awesome!

I never though I'd be that into a western but this presentation prooves me wrong. It helps that the game features a cast of familiar and yet diverse characters all interesting in its own right.

Gameplay while not complicated on the surfase is actually quite dynamic and even tactical with each move requiring you to plan  ahead and know what your enemies are capable of.

Matches are reletively easy to find and they last a comfortable 6 to 10 minutes.

No it is nothing like a dota moba, and yes it is a battle arena, only the arena where there is only you, your enemy and your skill.

It only just came out of early access (and for that I commend the devs and welcome them into the 'get it done' crowd) and while there are some rough edges it plays smoothly, never crashed on me even once and even though I live in middle-earth I have not had any network related issues at all.

I highly recommend this title!

reviewText:
A consoel port. Absolutely not recommended for PC gamers with even light quality standards.

The control scheme is utterly unintuitive, because the devs decided not to bother to create a proper PC control scheme and instead simply rebound the functions to the keyboard and mouse keys.

Animations constantly seize up, causing terrible visuals such as your character sliding around along the ground with legs paralyzed in a static position while reloading.

Actions don't have a fluidity/queue system implemented, meaning that chaining different actions together is unnecessarily rough, and this was in single player -- I can only imagine how bad it would be in multiplayer with even moderate latency.

And overall production quality is nothing to brag about either.

Yes, this is an indie game, but there is never, ever an excuse for not implementing a proper PC control scheme.

Cheap console ports are always unacceptable, regardless of any circumstances.

Couple that with lazy production efforts, and you get a mediocre game that controls awkwardly and lacks the depth to keep people playing even if everything else were polished.

reviewText:
This game ♥♥♥♥ here is why:

This review will be kinda short. (2 min read time)
First of all the most glaring thing, the perspektive. It sucks as as you begin because you only hit the feet of the people which is a complete mind♥♥♥♥. It also makes it very hard to gauge distance so you prob get outranged even though you shouldn't more on that later.
ATLEAST the idea is good. Never seen anything like this. Bright unique and lovely crafted characters. It reminds me a lot of Magicka which is just as unique (maybe a little more).
The next is the lvl/rank sytem (have this from TB I didn't play enough to get out of unranked) as you get a higher rank you level up your bandit which makes you stronger so higher rank=stronger character. You see the problem? Good. NEXT!
THIS GAME HAS AN ASSFULL OF POTENTIAL. It's not overly complicated and there for has quite a big margend to improve and out skill your opponent. But all the bugs and ♥♥♥♥ and lag make it impossible right now.
Now ALL THE BASIC FLAWS! IT'S RIDICLIOUS! It's an enhanced ♥♥♥♥ING EDITION! It lags like ♥♥♥♥ has a ♥♥♥♥ing huge exploit ( you can shoot while dashing *facepalm* ). I can't tell if it's the case that it lags to much so that I don't hit my enemy but he hits me, that my character has less range than anyone else or I just miss the shot and they hiz. I can't figure it out which. that is also a big problem you can't see your mistakes. There is no introduction for the chracters and not a lot of souce material. That fact makes it impossible to research how to play a character.

Overall nice idea/game but it's build into ♥♥♥♥ with exploits and bugs and lag...

reviewText:
I jumped on board for the free week event, and I was sold on this after getting a few hours into it.

The game is a lot more active than your typical MOBA, since everything you're doing is a skillshot. That can seem scary at first for inexperienced players, and you may get your face melted a few times as you learn, but it's infinitely more engaging once you get the hang of it, and more satisfying when you finally nail a game-changing shot.

The character classes all seem very well-balanced, and they accommodate the full range of play styles. You can run-and-gun, snipe, charge into melee, or play defense, and you can be pretty successful at any of them if you learn how to do it right.  There's also plenty of synergy between different classes, so even an OK team can pull off effective combos.

Maps are solid--enough space to maneuver but not enough that anyone disappears. The game could probably use another play mode or two, but the current ones have been enough to keep me busy.

Art style is... Well, take a look! It's beautiful. It's fun to watch even when your team's getting rolled, it almost it feel less painful.

And if you want dev support, you really can't beat it. Devs are in the chatroom for about half of every day.

Only thing that the game's been struggling with is its population... From what I hear, before the free week it was a ghost town, much like the in-game visuals. But a lot of people like myself joined for the free week and have decided to stay for the long haul, so the population issue is gradually ironing itself out. US matchmaking is good until about pre-dawn, EU is creeping upward, and Down Under is the only region that still needs a helping hand. But we're only halfway through with the promo as I type this and haven't even reached the weekend yet, so there's nowhere to go but up.

Final Note: The community that's already here has only a hint of salt in it... You get some overlap from the rest of the Interwebz, and there will be the occasional n00bs14y3r,  but nothing even CLOSE to the level that you'd expect from Dota2, LoL, etc. This may change as the game continues to grow, but right now it's in a pretty comfy place.

reviewText:
HI,

Initially I left a good review here because I liked the game when I started, I mean yes, the game has good graphics and a nice gameplay and it's well worth the money.
My best position in the ranked leaderboard was 3 and I might still be in top 10. Eventually this game gets very boring and you start focusing on the many bugs in the game. Yes that's right, another unfinished game you have to pay for, and it's not early access anymore.
Most positive reviews are from players who quit, but didn't change their review.
The customer service for this game is poor.
Part of the team that helped designing this game are interactive with the players, but do not expect anything special.
This game made me hate League of Legends a lot less. That's hard to believe, right? I know.
You know those reviews about Dota 2 saying you should never even start playing? Well at least games like League of Legends and Dota 2 are popular and you can earn money from playing them.

There is no reason for you to play this, there are a lot of good games out there, just pick something else.

reviewText:
When I first made this review it was because I played 4 ranked 3v3 games, and was immediately matched against the #1 Gordo and the #1 Deserter, literally players in the top 50 with no one else better than them at their characters. I then proceeded to matched against them 3 more times. Each time I lost about 140 points, since they slaughtered us at every turn. Couldn't even damage them.

Not only did they have a perk point advantage, they were clearly better than us skill wise too.

Did I mention we had only been playing for a few hours? And here we are in ranked, getting our ♥♥♥♥ pounded in, because the game’s player base seems to be dead on release.
As for an actual review I might as well add some points as to why I dislike the game. Besides the matchmaking.

GAME PLAY

It's actually fun. Each Outlaw is unique both art wise and ability wise. The art is done by the same people as Darkest Dungeon, so expect lots of character in this game.
There are a few latency issues which let you get hit by things that you may have seen yourself dodge but that’s something that plagues numerous other games, so I don’t expect an indie game to be immune to these issues.

The game feels satisfying, and would be fast paced, if not for the ♥♥♥♥ing timers and animations and post-game screens you have to sit through during, and after a game. This stuff makes my skin crawl. The last thing I want to do after a defeat is be forced to do ♥♥♥♥ing nothing for a solid 30 seconds. This is pretty well known in games that pauses and animations are nice in a game, but only when used conservatively. Take portal for example. When you die in portal, you instantly respawn at the beginning of the puzzle/checkpoint. In this game, when I die there’s a death timer/waiting for your ally to kill everyone/die. And then the post-game stats and ♥♥♥♥ can’t be instantly skipped. I should be able to press a key twice and have that ♥♥♥♥ gone from my view, because half of it doesn’t even matter when you just want to queue up again. But you have to be punished even further for your failure.

HUD

The hud is very minimal, which I like, but certain things aren’t displayed properly, with no way to know what they do. I understand that ~!!WOUNDED!!~ is bad. And that I should avoid that and try to do it to my enemies. But am I ♥♥♥♥ing slowed? Am I stunned/disarmed? Should I take cover should I not roll is my AIM ♥♥♥♥ed? Big red letters do me ♥♥♥♥ all if I don’t know what the ♥♥♥♥ is going on.
Besides from the total lack of information about status effects the hud doesn’t take up much screen space which, again, is always nice.
The camera angle naturally favors those who are beneath you, or yourself, if you’re below your enemy. This is because the camera angle is fixed at a tilt, and while visually pleasing means that your enemy will see you before you see them, in this case.

IN GAME MENUS

Ported straight from a console game folks. You can’t even change the horrendous bindings. I should be able to navigate the menu with one hand. Or at least be able to use my mouse. But I have to hit ♥♥♥♥ing enter. Ya know, that one key ♥♥♥♥ING MILES away from wasd. I thought this was a core of gameplay design? You bind that ♥♥♥♥ to spacebar. Always. No exceptions. It’s inconvenient and annoys the player.

OVERALL
Great gameplay broken up by frustrating pauses in gameplay and bad Menus which only serve to frustrate the player.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

***Only buy it if you can tolerate a lot of bugs and you are calm as a stoned sloth after a 100 hours nap!***

I'm very sorry to say this, but THE GAME IN ITS CURRENT STATE IS A HUGE PILE OF CRAP! Not even worth a cent!
I know it's BETA and ported from PS4, but c'mon developers, do your job!

After 6 hours of playing:
CONS:
- crap matchmaking system
- lots of times one of the gang members drop from game and it gets 1v2, 3v4 (or any odd vs. even number of gang members)
- you can easily face two or more enemy who are almost gods based on their ranks, while you are totally newb
- limited game modes: you can play only parctice and on additional mode, which is defined by the game, no change option available
- no in-game communication option
- no character balance
- annoying end-match slow motion animation
- no Alt+Tab option (game changes to windowed mode and cannot switch it back)

PROS:
- nice visuals
- so-so physics
- it was 40% off

After all of this, I keep practicing and hope the above things will be fixed soon. I don't want to waste my money on ♥♥♥♥ games.

reviewText:
Do not buy the game until they fix the lagging problem. What's the point in the game that is all about aiming and quick reflexes when every second enemy / team member has bad 1mb net connection and warps around the map?

Idea and gameplay is exellent but the game is unplayable at it's current state. Also there are not many players since matchmaking (which basically just puts anyone possible in same match with anyone possible) takes sometimes up to 10 mins. Rounds last 20seconds - few minutes and waiting for new game takes long. Also atleast for me 2v2 feels too few. 5v5 and 10 v 10 would be more chaotic and fun.

Game also suffers from countles graphics bugs which occurs 100% every round. Most notable is the blue map where everything is invisible exept players and this does not happen to everyone sametime so it makes you to be true underdog. Not being able to see where walls etc is when enemy can makes it quite hard to survive.

Also since people with toaster computers and hamster powered net connections usually DC before round even starts making you to fight alone versus 2 enemies which would actually be cool (I like challenge) otherwise but then you realize your enemies run on bikepowered net connections and warp around the map while you take dmg and get stunned from invisible bullets in all blue world where you can see only yourself.

The point is that all this would be ok" if it happened once a while. But 99% of the rounds.... *shakes head*..."

reviewText:
Facts:
-An overview game using mouse and keyboard to move and shoot.
-Everyone has a certain amount of health.
-There are about 10 classes
-There are many achievements, well integrated in the game where if you complete a group of achievements you get extra bonuses

Pros:
-Easy to learn and get into
-Cheap
-Matches start fast
-Fun to some extent with that extra addictive factor

Cons:
-Imbalanced. Some classes are balanced, while some classes can wreck you without skill due to tiny flaws with their build.

I would not at all recommend this game. The reviews and so on were so braggy about this game that I did buy it, but it's just disappointing. The game itself is very small. If the small price is too good to be true, then at least for this game, it's because it is.

Luckily I bought Secret Ponchos during the buy one get one free humble bundle sale but unless you're getting this game for free, I would not suggest buying this game since any money you put in will probably lead to that value being wasted.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There's nothing I like more than loading up, whipping a girl like a European sex festival, and proceeding to shove my double barreled shotgun inside of her, and repeatedly pulling the trigger.. 4 times before I'm out of ammo.

Small quirks aside, Secret Ponchos is a rather amazing little Quick-Twitch arena shooter, and a great game to share. You'll get 2v2 queues solidly, and with another person on comms, it becomes a rather delightful team building exercise of murdering other people together.

If you're into whipping, shotgunning, and overall twitch shooters, I'd recommend this game more than anything for the money. I feel it's worth it.

Early Access Review

Recently picked this up from a recommendation from a friend.

It took me a little time to get used to and it is still a bit rough around the edges but now that I've got into it I am loving it.

There is still work to be done (as would be expected from any early access game) but the developers are keen to listen and are very active in taking up suggestions or informing on changes to come. It's a different kind of game to most I have played with inspirations from MOBAs and fighting games.

It's quick to pick up but difficult to master and great fun with a gang of friends, I would recommend.

Looking forward to when the game is fully finished!

Early Access Review

reviewText:
A great game with some balancing issues and strange game mode limitations; any issues I have with the game can be fixed. This is a game so close to being fantastic that it deserves a little more attention which I'm sure the devs are going to provide anyway.

Pros:
- Beautiful, clear, informative art style, those character designs are incredible.
- Slick controls that feel great to use.
- Fantastic soundtrack for the most part
- Core gameplay is extremely fun with deeper strategic layers slowly becoming more apparent as you play.
- Level design is tight and levels don't feel larger than they need to be. Rich in character.

Cons:
- Strange, arbitrary game mode restrictions (why only 2v2 in unranked and 8 player in private match?)
- Characters unique abilities hidden in an in-game menu, which the game can't be paused while reading said information.  Making you vulnerable. Put those combo descriptions on the character selection screen instead.
- Possible problem with ranked perks that boosts seasoned players even further ahead than newer players, which are often found in the same games due to either poor matchmaking or a small player base.
- Tutorial seems to be bare-bones and doesn't feel like it covers all of the basics.
- Really bad bot AI
- Only problem with sound is the trumpet sound that is jarring and annoying when picking an online game / partying with other players. Maybe a slightly softer distant bell toll would help instead?

All the cons I've listed are really just nitpicks that seem like they can be patched out. Again, this is a great game held back by small problems and really deserves to be pushed just that little bit further. Me and my friends bought a 4 pack and don't regret it at all.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
A pleasant surprise! I honestly didn't expect much, and bought the game because it was on a small sale and I was looking for more Local Co-Op games. Sad to hear there isn't any Local Co-Op (Yet, it is on the works), but what I found was an incredibly deep arena game, with an astoinishingly well made art style to acccompany it.

Essentially you are a wanted man/woman/crazyperson in a town called Lonetree, where the only rule to exist is: hunt or be hunted. The game is technically a twin stick shooter, but that's a very rough explanation. I'd describe it as a mix between a moba, a twin stick shooter and old western films.

You start the game by picking 1 of 10 unique characters. Afterwards, you can practise with bots or go online for Unranked or Ranked play. And when you surprisingly quickly find a match, you get... decimated, and realise the game has such a high skill ceiling, you feel like you're in an open space. Combos, resource management, stressful decision making and more.

Honestly, it's a hard game to describe and the only con of it is the small playerbase, which can be fixed by you buying the game. So whaddaya waitin' for? Get busy shooting, or get busy dying.

reviewText:
Great Competitive Game
Introduction
Let me start by saying, I am quite new to this game but from what I've seen so far this is shaping up to be great game tat can only improve. There are only a few minor things which I think are holding it back, few of which are gameplay oriented.

Pros
Fast paced cometitive gameplay
Great variety in character abilities
Characters are balenced
The community is supportive and devs are active

Cons
The chat system is lacking team chat, making it difficult to stratigise with teammates.
The menu intferace feels a little clunky, buttons don't work like you feel they should. (escape does not take you to the pervious menu for instance).
You will often be matched with higher level players, however even if you lose you will still level your character due to points being awarded for damage dealt and compensation playing agaisnt higher level players.

All in all I feel like this game has improvments to make and could benifit form having a league based system implemented. However it's already an engaging and fun experiance with several layers of depth.

reviewText:
It feels like an Early Access with a lot of unrealized potential. Mostly with the skill cards. Its where the life of the characters, and game, reside.

-Typos (See Poncho's Skillcard)
-Last few skill cards just repeat the short character bio which implies laziness compared to the slight expansion of the character backgrounds from the earlier characters.
-I feel like practice mode could be polished up a bit, including adding the option to view skill cards.

It lacks a je ne se quai. Action happens, but theres no depth beyond shooting. What this game would wildly benefit from is characters with personalities. Currently they shoot and move in basic silence except for gunfire and muted grunts. They need quips, voices and interactions. We're at that point in videogaming where character depth is more than just the way they look, especially in a game that lacks any sort of story or exposition beyond a few sentences.

Its fun, but the problem is the fact that it gets boring quickly. There is absolutely ZERO investment to make me want to keep going with the characters. Once you play them, thats all there is to them, theres nothing left to learn or unlock or discover about the most important part of a PvP fighting game.

Also, on a small personal thing, the inconsistency with the Solid White eyes being prevalent except for a few characters irks me.

Wouldnt pay 15 for it, not quite as is, it just feels a little unfinished and unrealized.
