reviewText:
Context: I am recommending this with some notable reservations that you should bear in mind before buying.

I got to try the game during the free week promotion, and I must admit, from a design standpoint, the game is solid. The art direction is likewise spectacular. Matchmaking, however, is absolutely abyssmal. The lack of offline content besides a 2 vs. 2 mode and a 1 vs 1 ladder Arcade mode really holds the game back as well for those who have trouble connecting. That all said, when you can get in a good match online, Secret Ponchos is easily one of the best twin-stick competitive shooters released in quite some time.

The variety of characters is welcome, and each handles distinctly. For example: the Matador is the close-range damage dealer, while KidRed peppers enemies with his six shooters, and Poncho controls the ebb and flow of battle with his shotgun and whip. The map selection also have several notable highlights, including a midnight saloon shootout and a crashsite from a train robbery gone wrong. The modes, however, are limited to Deathmatch (one life, no respawns, 3 vs. 3), Posse (Guard one VIP, take out the other team's VIP), and another mode that combines tug of war with traditional Team Deathmatch. There's also 1 vs. 1 fights, and those can feel more akin to a fighting game than you'd expect, but overall, most people will be interested in the team modes.

If I were to make a direct suggestion to the developers, I'd strongly advise for some form of cooperative multiplayer modes, and along with that, the possibility of a 5 vs. 5 mode. The maps feel like they could support larger scale battles, and fighting waves of bandits would be quite welcome as well. Most importantly though, I cannot emphasize this enough -- THE MATCHMAKING NEEDS FIXED. It is truly terrible at many points, especially when playing in a party with even just one friend. I know this is an indie production but really, this game needs to polish up the networking side of things if it wants to last.

So, should you get Secret Ponchos? Definitely if it's on sale, but at full price, the game lacks the polish it clearly has in other areas. The dev team have a strong direction and talent with game design that I hope they'll be able to put to use in future titles, but they have got to get someone to clean up the netcode.

This game is fantastic.

Great art style, a cartoony but gritty look which fits each character nicely. Speaking of, the characters are all interesting and play differently with unique skills to each and the ability to customize them a bit gives them personality.  You've got everything classic covered, from your native american warriors, to the former soldier, young gun , spooky supernatural bandito and others.

The music is very well done and gets you going for some wild shoot outs and has a nice cinematic feel.  The cover system is neat and overall the gameplay is fast and results in furious matches that usually end in some appropriately epic way.  The maps are laid out well and have cool details to see as you dive around corners or behind tables, weave in and out of train cars, or run through an old town. Very fun and reccomended for anyone who likes quickdraw slick gun battles in the old west.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

UPDATED REVIEW (30th June 2015):

I gave the game a second try after discussing it with one of the developers (he was so kind to come and ask for my feedback, oh man, we need more developers like these guys!).
This time, I tested the game with a friend. After the initial struggle from my lack of skill, the game started getting more and more interesting the more we played it.
Covers became helpful, hiding became very important and I finally managed to keep enemies far from me.

My suggestion is, keep playing when you feel it's time to drop off, the game has MUCH more to offer once you get more used to it. It gets very interesting all that cover-stealth-shoot gameplay and I love how you can use the evade move not only to avoid being shoot, but also to cover long distance which makes extremely helpful when you need to take cover, hide and reload.

Stay tuned for further updates, it's time to play Secret Ponchos a bit more ;)

FIRST REVIEW

The graphic is STUNNING, however the gameplay as of this date, felt extremely dull. Instead of promoting a somewhat ranged combat, we ended up playing mostly on short range (or even melee), and even there it wasn't really interesting.

I'll wait until out of early access

reviewText:
Me 'an three other rough-lookin' dusters swept into town, each of us with iron as company. We left quite a few shots in the saloon. And in the saloon the three other fellas. And in the three fellas... well, quite a few bullets.

This ain't a pick-up and play game- it takes skill and planning to be the roughest gang out there.

Pros:
- Skill game, not a button mashing pick-me-up.
- Art style/Character and level design.
- Fast, competetive gamplay that'll make yer sweat bullets.
- Just plain 'ole fun for a 15$ indie game. (7$ until the 21st of december 2015.)
- Sound and music fits perfectly to the point of making me laugh whenever I start matches.

Cons:
- Not many levels.
- Only a few game modes.
- Some characters (Yes, you wolf girl.) are underpowered compared to other characters.
- A few (not many really) connection issues during matchmaking.

If you don't like the game now becuase of lack of content or matchmaking, give it a year, and it'll blow your socks off. This game is truly fun!

reviewText:
It feels like an Early Access with a lot of unrealized potential. Mostly with the skill cards. Its where the life of the characters, and game, reside.

-Typos (See Poncho's Skillcard)
-Last few skill cards just repeat the short character bio which implies laziness compared to the slight expansion of the character backgrounds from the earlier characters.
-I feel like practice mode could be polished up a bit, including adding the option to view skill cards.

It lacks a je ne se quai. Action happens, but theres no depth beyond shooting. What this game would wildly benefit from is characters with personalities. Currently they shoot and move in basic silence except for gunfire and muted grunts. They need quips, voices and interactions. We're at that point in videogaming where character depth is more than just the way they look, especially in a game that lacks any sort of story or exposition beyond a few sentences.

Its fun, but the problem is the fact that it gets boring quickly. There is absolutely ZERO investment to make me want to keep going with the characters. Once you play them, thats all there is to them, theres nothing left to learn or unlock or discover about the most important part of a PvP fighting game.

Also, on a small personal thing, the inconsistency with the Solid White eyes being prevalent except for a few characters irks me.

Wouldnt pay 15 for it, not quite as is, it just feels a little unfinished and unrealized.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
What an amazingly simple, addictive and engaging game!

Secret Ponchos is a breath of fresh air in an increasing stale team competition environment that, for the most part, emphasizes the importance of gear, stats, builds and cookie-cutter strategies. Matchmaking is easy. The characters are quirky, and they appeal to a broad range of play styles. And small elements of the MOBA format are blended seemlessly with fast-paced isometric twitch shooting in such a way as to not be overbearing, complicated or inaccessible. Secret Ponchos is casual good times, and its community is a friendly, fun-loving one. The $9.99 customization DLC is well worth it too. Bombed-out Kid Red is pure hilarious eye candy.

I can't reccomend it enough. In fact, Secret Ponchos is so damn good that I actually bothered to write a Steam review of it. Unthinkable! Buy it, lose yourself in it, and enjoy a well-earned break from organizing stacks of building materials and consumables in the rushed-out early access survival game you are currently playing and are no doubt already getting sick to death of.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Secret Ponchos is an amazingly fresh and beautiful take on the twitch fighting genre. The developers have put together a very tight package where the artwork, style, learning curve, controls, music, environments, etc. are all extremely well considered, put together and complimentary. The minute you open the game, you notice the artwork and the design, and then as you play, you are happy to notice that the mechanics and gameplay hold pace and do not disappoint.

It's hard to classify this game in comparison to other games because it's not like much else I've ever played, but if I had to pull from other games I would say that it shares:
- Twitch style controlling of a Street Fighter game (unless you're a button masher). It's not a point and unload your clip kind of game. Every shot is a skilled considered button push and can combo out with your other moves" and every movement of your character is a considered move in relation to the positioning of your opponents and the map.
- MOBA style arena. Not in that you have a set spawn point and half the map is kind of yours
date:
but pretty much only in the way that you have an isometric viewpoint and there is a large arena where two teams battle (unless you're in free-for-all mode).

Throw those elements into a fast paced beautiful spaghetti western environment and you've got yourself Secret Ponchos.

As for the game play: There are 10 characters to choose from and they all cater to different play styles and learning curves. Unlike street fighter
recommended: there is not a dozen or more moves to master. Each character has about 4-5 unique moves that can also potentially combo for devastating effects. But these moves are very nuanced in their execution and very reactive to the conditions around you. You never feel at a lack of moves/attacks to use when playing a specific character.\n\nSome characters you can jump right into and expect a couple kills per match
hoursPlayed: others you will need to master. All characters though - as I have experienced first hand - can be very deadly in professional hands. And this is the good thing: every character
voteText: and the game itself
helpfulPercent: have a high ceiling in terms of skill. Even the characters that are easy to immediately play with have a lot of subtle nuance that takes a long time to perfect. And how you play according to your environment and your opponents/teammates takes a long time to even begin to master.\n\nThis does create a skill deferential between the pros and the newcomers
votesHelpful: but a rookie lobby
votesFunny: and an intelligent progression system (explained below) all help the fact that a relative rookie still has a decent chance at gunning down a pro a couple times per match (and it's not like a pro/rookie skill differential has prevented people from playing other games such as COD).\n\nThe manner in which your character progresses is one of my favourite aspects of this game. As opposed to an empty and overused "Experience Points = Level Up" sort of structure
commentsCount: the developers have gone with something that suits the genre and the vibe of a Wild West setting. Instead of collecting experience
column16: you collect notoriety. And much like the real world
column17: notoriety can come and go; you play very well and you gain notoriety
column19: you will lose notoriety. For me this is a welcome change
column20: and something I have been secretly desiring out of more games of late. No more players who don't cooperate with their team because they want to get the "throw back grenade achievement" (I'm looking at you COD Black Ops).\n\nEveryone feels like their neck is on the line and it makes the game play riveting and exhilarating. The important thing here too is that it's well balanced. A loss will never strip away so much notoriety that you will feel devastated and ready to quit the game. And for rookies starting out
column21: each match calculates your odds of doing well
column22: and the notoriety you gain/lose is in relation to those odds. So if you play a group of pros
column23: you can still gain notoriety if you lost but still successfully dealt some damage or made some kills. TO NOTE: this progression is specific to each of your characters
column24: so if you want to try out a new character or a new play style
column25: you can do so without influencing the notoriety of your star player.\n\nAs you do gain notoriety
column26: you get to drop a couple points into various skills (damage
column30: etc). These points don't come often though and are well balanced so that the differences it creates between a rookie character and a pro character is noticeable but not so distancing that there is no competition between the two.\n\nEverything in this game (the setting
column33: etc.) leads to a very strong and cohesive immersive
column35: fast paced game where you can really feel your character gaining notoriety
column36: and feel your skills improve. On top of that it's fun!\n\nI would strongly recommend trying this title out as it's a wonderfully styled and scored adrenalin rush to play! And to top it off
column37: there is a strong dev team that play the game and consider and respond daily to issues
column38: ideas and concerns that the community has. Their supportive and friendly attitude seems to trickle down into the community
column39: forming a supportive and friendly player base.\n\nAnd to those curious about the community of this pvp-only game: since launch it has been growing steadily and I have found no dead times where I couldn't find a match. I only see it getting better and I am looking forward to a growing strong and friendly player base!"

Highly addictive game with relatively simple mechanics and high skill cap.
Some outlaws (characters) are easier then others of course, but to truly master each one is an art in and of itself. Art style is simply amazing, I fell in love at it on first sight, see for yourself how good it is. Music and sound is also great.

My rating would be 8,5/10.

reviewText:
A great game with some balancing issues and strange game mode limitations; any issues I have with the game can be fixed. This is a game so close to being fantastic that it deserves a little more attention which I'm sure the devs are going to provide anyway.

Pros:
- Beautiful, clear, informative art style, those character designs are incredible.
- Slick controls that feel great to use.
- Fantastic soundtrack for the most part
- Core gameplay is extremely fun with deeper strategic layers slowly becoming more apparent as you play.
- Level design is tight and levels don't feel larger than they need to be. Rich in character.

Cons:
- Strange, arbitrary game mode restrictions (why only 2v2 in unranked and 8 player in private match?)
- Characters unique abilities hidden in an in-game menu, which the game can't be paused while reading said information.  Making you vulnerable. Put those combo descriptions on the character selection screen instead.
- Possible problem with ranked perks that boosts seasoned players even further ahead than newer players, which are often found in the same games due to either poor matchmaking or a small player base.
- Tutorial seems to be bare-bones and doesn't feel like it covers all of the basics.
- Really bad bot AI
- Only problem with sound is the trumpet sound that is jarring and annoying when picking an online game / partying with other players. Maybe a slightly softer distant bell toll would help instead?

All the cons I've listed are really just nitpicks that seem like they can be patched out. Again, this is a great game held back by small problems and really deserves to be pushed just that little bit further. Me and my friends bought a 4 pack and don't regret it at all.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
A pleasant surprise! I honestly didn't expect much, and bought the game because it was on a small sale and I was looking for more Local Co-Op games. Sad to hear there isn't any Local Co-Op (Yet, it is on the works), but what I found was an incredibly deep arena game, with an astoinishingly well made art style to acccompany it.

Essentially you are a wanted man/woman/crazyperson in a town called Lonetree, where the only rule to exist is: hunt or be hunted. The game is technically a twin stick shooter, but that's a very rough explanation. I'd describe it as a mix between a moba, a twin stick shooter and old western films.

You start the game by picking 1 of 10 unique characters. Afterwards, you can practise with bots or go online for Unranked or Ranked play. And when you surprisingly quickly find a match, you get... decimated, and realise the game has such a high skill ceiling, you feel like you're in an open space. Combos, resource management, stressful decision making and more.

Honestly, it's a hard game to describe and the only con of it is the small playerbase, which can be fixed by you buying the game. So whaddaya waitin' for? Get busy shooting, or get busy dying.

reviewText:
This is an arena game in which we face other players using different kinds of characters and selecting various attacks, which reminds me of MOBA type games. There are Skillshots, and a lot of skill is needed to avoid attacks from enemy players by using acrobatics or tactical moves, which also adds a touch of fighting game, leaving us with a mixture of genres.

Another notable aspect of this game is its particular aesthetic, and how they have developed the characters, which seem drawn from some animated cartoon, each modeled after the archetypal characters that can be found in spaghetti westerns.

All these elements, combined with the fluidity, speed, and the theme make this game something interesting and refreshing, specially if you like PvP games.

Matchmaking is easy. The characters are quirky, and they appeal to a broad range of play styles. And small elements of the MOBA format are blended seemlessly with fast-paced isometric twitch shooting in such a way as to not be overbearing, complicated or inaccessible. Secret Ponchos is casual good times, and its community is a friendly, fun-loving one. The $9.99 customization DLC is well worth it too. Bombed-out Kid Red is pure hilarious eye candy.

I can't reccomend it enough. In fact, Secret Ponchos is so damn good that I actually bothered to write a Steam review of it. Unthinkable! Buy it, lose yourself in it, and enjoy a well-earned break from organizing stacks of building materials and consumables in the rushed-out early access survival game you are currently playing and are no doubt already getting sick to death of.

reviewText:
Secret Ponchos is an amazingly fresh and beautiful take on the twitch fighting genre. The developers have put together a very tight package where the artwork, style, learning curve, controls, music, environments, etc. are all extremely well considered, put together and complimentary. The minute you open the game, you notice the artwork and the design, and then as you play, you are happy to notice that the mechanics and gameplay hold pace and do not disappoint.

It's hard to classify this game in comparison to other games because it's not like much else I've ever played, but if I had to pull from other games I would say that it shares:
- Twitch style controlling of a Street Fighter game (unless you're a button masher). It's not a point and unload your clip kind of game. Every shot is a skilled considered button push and can combo out with your other moves" and every movement of your character is a considered move in relation to the positioning of your opponents and the map.
- MOBA style arena. Not in that you have a set spawn point and half the map is kind of yours
date:
but pretty much only in the way that you have an isometric viewpoint and there is a large arena where two teams battle (unless you're in free-for-all mode).

Throw those elements into a fast paced beautiful spaghetti western environment and you've got yourself Secret Ponchos.

As for the game play: There are 10 characters to choose from and they all cater to different play styles and learning curves. Unlike street fighter
recommended: there is not a dozen or more moves to master. Each character has about 4-5 unique moves that can also potentially combo for devastating effects. But these moves are very nuanced in their execution and very reactive to the conditions around you. You never feel at a lack of moves/attacks to use when playing a specific character.\n\nSome characters you can jump right into and expect a couple kills per match
hoursPlayed: others you will need to master. All characters though - as I have experienced first hand - can be very deadly in professional hands. And this is the good thing: every character
voteText: and the game itself
helpfulPercent: have a high ceiling in terms of skill. Even the characters that are easy to immediately play with have a lot of subtle nuance that takes a long time to perfect. And how you play according to your environment and your opponents/teammates takes a long time to even begin to master.\n\nThis does create a skill deferential between the pros and the newcomers
votesHelpful: but a rookie lobby
votesFunny: and an intelligent progression system (explained below) all help the fact that a relative rookie still has a decent chance at gunning down a pro a couple times per match (and it's not like a pro/rookie skill differential has prevented people from playing other games such as COD).\n\nThe manner in which your character progresses is one of my favourite aspects of this game. As opposed to an empty and overused "Experience Points = Level Up" sort of structure
commentsCount: the developers have gone with something that suits the genre and the vibe of a Wild West setting. Instead of collecting experience
column16: you collect notoriety. And much like the real world
column17: notoriety can come and go; you play very well and you gain notoriety
column19: you will lose notoriety. For me this is a welcome change
column20: and something I have been secretly desiring out of more games of late. No more players who don't cooperate with their team because they want to get the "throw back grenade achievement" (I'm looking at you COD Black Ops).\n\nEveryone feels like their neck is on the line and it makes the game play riveting and exhilarating. The important thing here too is that it's well balanced. A loss will never strip away so much notoriety that you will feel devastated and ready to quit the game. And for rookies starting out
column21: each match calculates your odds of doing well
column22: and the notoriety you gain/lose is in relation to those odds. So if you play a group of pros
column23: you can still gain notoriety if you lost but still successfully dealt some damage or made some kills. TO NOTE: this progression is specific to each of your characters
column24: so if you want to try out a new character or a new play style
column25: you can do so without influencing the notoriety of your star player.\n\nAs you do gain notoriety
column26: you get to drop a couple points into various skills (damage
column30: etc). These points don't come often though and are well balanced so that the differences it creates between a rookie character and a pro character is noticeable but not so distancing that there is no competition between the two.\n\nEverything in this game (the setting
column33: etc.) leads to a very strong and cohesive immersive
column35: fast paced game where you can really feel your character gaining notoriety
column36: and feel your skills improve. On top of that it's fun!\n\nI would strongly recommend trying this title out as it's a wonderfully styled and scored adrenalin rush to play! And to top it off
column37: there is a strong dev team that play the game and consider and respond daily to issues
column38: ideas and concerns that the community has. Their supportive and friendly attitude seems to trickle down into the community
column39: forming a supportive and friendly player base.\n\nAnd to those curious about the community of this pvp-only game: since launch it has been growing steadily and I have found no dead times where I couldn't find a match. I only see it getting better and I am looking forward to a growing strong and friendly player base!"

reviewText:
A wild west romp with gunslinging action.

So multiplayer indie games are tough things. Hard to make, hard to keep populated, but they're clearly labors of love and this one is no exception.

Pros:
First, massive kudos to the clever mechanics, distinct art style, and slick character design.
Second, the game is fun. Simple as that. It's just enjoyable to gun someone down as they dive for cover or toss a well timed explosive into their path.

Cons:
There's some oddities with both balance and lag. I believe these things can all be fixed.

Lawman for life! (Except in 1v1 where he sucks).

reviewText:
Secret Ponchos...
This game surprised me out of the blue. It is and old west kinda stickfigure shooter, and my god it is amazing. I would no doubt recommend this game to anyone, it has alot of depth, the matches are intense and the skill ceiling on this game is  high as balls. I heard about the competitive side of Secret Ponchos had an astonishing potential and I kinda doubted it. Well it has.
If you like the amazing aesthetic this has to offer, old wild west appeals to you you should get this game for some Outlaw intense experience matches.

Now I wish everything in this review was positive, I really really did because the game blew me away in surprise and sucked me in. But there is a big negative here and it is the community. People here are the friendliest I've ever seen in any game in years, but it is really really small.. If you are a late night time player, the sad truth at the moment is that you might not get any matches at all.. It takes sometimes a really long time to find a match, fortunatly because of this people tend to stick with each other after the match, so in my experience when you find one you are pretty much set and the next matches will be quick if not instant since the game gives you a rematch option.

It boggles my mind how the player base is so small for this amazing game, it really really REALLY deserves so much more. I could honestly see this game with a strong viewership on twitch for example it has that potential.
I'd say this happened because of the poor advertising and proprer word spreading of the game. From my understanding this game has been in early acess for at least an year I think? And I've never heard of it. Ever. I can't see any place other than a very very small percentage of youtubers that make a few videos here and there to Secret Ponchos where I would find this game.

Now I've been going to forums and the developers are aware and are going to implement features, possibly changing the rules" for a bigger player base so there is hope since the developers are actually pretty active with the community it seems.

So honestly
date: I wish I could be a ♥♥♥♥ and not say this negative side just so more people would buy and the playerbase to grow
recommended: but I can't be that ♥♥♥♥. Would and do I still recommend it? YES. When you get a match is amazing
hoursPlayed: and since the game is NOT abandoned by any means witha ctive developers announcing they are going to further look and fix this issue I would say it is still a relative safe bet. Because honestly I know the developers know they made an amazing game. I know it is an amazing game and the fault I would put in very poor advertising. This game is a hidden gem

reviewText:
This game, may not look like much on the cover, but HOLY DAM the game proves its much more then it seems, the game is brilliant and fun, the heros you can play are customizeable, from skill points, to skins to what your name is on your outlaw. You can play for hours, and if you like arena game play, like a MOBA type of game, than this game is good for you. Its easy to get use to, its countless hours of trying to get you bounty higher and killing other outlaws with friends or alown.

Pros:
-Easy to get a hold of the controls.
-Lots of fun Outlaws to play.
-Customizable Outlaws to make you'rs unique.
-Up to 2 friends to help kick but with, have a 3v3 or have an 8 people free-for-all with friends togeather.
-The community is friendly and not toxic, (99.9%)
-Easy to get addicted.
-its fun even without friends
-lots of diffrent maps to battle on

Cons:
-Might find it hard to stop playing at times.
-Outlaw skins require real payment or lots of hard spent time, sweat and tears to get.
-room can only hold so much people,

Overall: This game is fun, I only played around 39 hours, or somewhere, but this game has been my goto game when I was stressed, and when I needed a break. This is on my opinion, people who like MOBA style games will like this one, people who like bounty hunters will like this game, and people who like a PvP aspect will like this game aswell,
I would rate it a 9.5 out of 10 becuase the game is stuning, and exciting. the last 0.5 is becuase well, I didn't have any friends playing with me, so I am not sure.

I hope this review is helpful to you guys looking at this game. note this is off my own perspective on a game. And also note that this is the first review that I have made that is this long and detailed.

reviewText:
EDITED 11/15/2015

After a few months, the game has lost it's population due to unfixed issues.  I can no longer call this  my pick for Game of the Year.  In fact, I wouldn't even recommend the game.  If you want hardcore PvP, this isn't going to be it.  The lag issues as well as the way the devs have balanced mechanics have broken the game to the point where it will not be competitive.  If you want a seriously good free PvP game, try Brawlhalla.  In case the game becomes good again,  I will update this review, but as of right now, I cannot recommend this game to people reading my review.  Save your money and wait for this to go free to play.

Below is my previous review of the game at launch.

I'm a hardcore PvP'er and 2015 has seen a complete lack of good PvP games.  Secret Ponchos has finally brought a breath of fresh air with their PvP Arena style combat.  This game takes my vote Game of the Year easily.  At the current price, it is well worth the money for the quality of graphics and polish on the game.  If you have been wanting a good PvP game, this is it.

Fair warning, the PvP in this is developed and there are really good players around.  The one drawback is that the game has not been marketed with tons of cash as it's an indy game.  So the game population is low and they're balancing between good quality matches and a reasonable queue time for matches.

If you decide to get this game, realize that you may fight some players who crush you.  It's okay, learn from your mistakes and grow and get better.  The game isn't for the faint of heart who easily give up and blame the balance of the game.  It's fairly balanced in 1v1s and very balanced in 3v3s.

Again, if you like arena style PvP, get this game and come try to take me down.  I could use fresh meat.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
This game is really fun to play especially with friend. It is full PvP, easy to pick up but hard to master.

However, my game craches 1/2 times. I can't even run the game smoothly at the lowest graphics. Speaking about graphics, the options are like non-existant. You cannot change the resolution. You can only change the overall graphics (low, medium, high), fullscreen or windowed mode and Vsync activation or not.

I mean this game didn't look like you needed a really good computer to play without bugs.
With my computer I can run Ultra Street Fighter IV, League of legends, CSGO, Fifa 16 etc. with really good graphics, but even with the lowest graphics, I can't run this game smoothly.

So yeah, be careful before buying this game, because you need a better computer than it seems.


Exept from that, the idea of the game is really cool, the concept is amazing.

Let's see in the future, but for now I don't even want to play it anymore.

It's hard to say but I don't recommand it yet. It took 6 years for the developpers to do this game so I don't think they will drop the project. Just waiting for the right updates.

EDIT: The developper got back to me after this review to ask for my specs etc. I forgot to answer but today i launched the game to see if anything was better and the game run smoothly now with high quality.

So you can forget about all the cons in my review because they have been solved somehow.

Buy the game and enjoy :) Help them get a wider community

reviewText: Secret Ponchos is a great game for anyone who enjoys competition and skill-based pvp combat.  The community is small but dedicated and the developers are great about listening to feedback and having visibility in chat/forums.  The game is fairly balanced, with characters being tuned up or down as needed.  Small changes are made which is a good way to balance as no character is super weak or super strong, at least in my opinion.  Ultimately, a great buy for anyone who enjoys the western theme and fast-paced combat style.

reviewText: Great idea, very enjoyable execution, but no players. Steam chart shows that the average from January to 6/1 is about 3 players online at any time. The problem is that there are so many great multiplayer games out there now competing for what is ultimately a fairly small pool of players. Secret Ponches has just lost the interest of too many players, so it\'s not worth it.
